classes.name: Block
classes.description: A block in a world. It has a location and a type, and can also have a direction (mostly a facing), an inventory, or other special properties.

classes.name: Block Data
classes.description: Block data is the detailed information about a block, referred to in Minecraft as BlockStates, allowing for the manipulation of different aspects of the block, including shape, waterlogging, direction the block is facing, and so much more. Information regarding each block's optional data can be found on Minecraft's Wiki. Find the block you're looking for and scroll down to 'Block States'. Different states must be separated by a semicolon (see examples). The 'minecraft:' namespace is optional, as well as are underscores.
classes.examples:
set block at player to campfire[lit=false]
set target block of player to oak stairs[facing=north;waterlogged=true]
set block at player to grass_block[snowy=true]
set loop-block to minecraft:chest[facing=north]
set block above player to oak_log[axis=y]
set target block of player to minecraft:oak_leaves[distance=2;persistent=false]

classes.name: Boolean
classes.description: A boolean is a value that is either true or false. Other accepted names are 'on' and 'yes' for true, and 'off' and 'no' for false.

classes.name: Config
classes.description:
A configuration (or code) loaded by Skript, such as the config.sk or aliases.
Configs can be reloaded or navigated to find options.

The cause/type of a damage event, e.g. lava, fall, fire, drowning, explosion, poison, etc.
Please note that support for this type is very rudimentary, e.g. lava, fire and burning, as well as projectile and attack are considered different types.

classes.name: Date
classes.description:
A date is a certain point in the real world's time which can be obtained with now expression, unix date expression and date function.
See time and timespan for the other time types of Skript.
classes.examples:
set {_yesterday} to now
subtract a day from {_yesterday}
# now {_yesterday} represents the date 24 hours before now

classes.name: Difficulty
classes.description: The difficulty of a world.

classes.name: Direction
classes.description:
A direction, e.g. north, east, behind, 5 south east, 1.3 meters to the right, etc.
Locations and some blocks also have a direction, but without a length.
Please note that directions have changed extensively in the betas and might not work perfectly. They can also not be used as command arguments.
classes.examples:
set the block below the victim to a chest
loop blocks from the block infront of the player to the block 10 below the player:
set the block behind the loop-block to water

entity is a zombie or creeper
player is an op
projectile is an arrow
shoot a fireball from the player

classes.name: Entity Snapshot
classes.description:
Represents a snapshot of an entity's data.
This includes all of the data associated with an entity (its name, health, attributes, etc.), at the time this expression is used. Essentially, these are a way to create templates for entities.
Individual attributes of a snapshot cannot be modified or retrieved.

classes.name: Entity Type
classes.description: The type of an entity, e.g. player, wolf, powered creeper, etc.
classes.examples:
victim is a cow
spawn a creeper

classes.name: Entity Type with Amount
classes.description: An entity type with an amount, e.g. '2 zombies'. I might remove this type in the future and make a more general 'type' type, i.e. a type that has a number and a type.

classes.name: Executable
classes.description:
Something that can be executed (run) and may accept arguments, e.g. a function.
This may also return a result.

classes.name: Experience
classes.description: Experience points. Please note that Bukkit only allows to give XP, but not remove XP from players. You can however change a player's level and level progress freely.

classes.name: Experience Cooldown Change Reason
classes.description: Represents a change reason of an experience cooldown change event.

classes.name: Firework Effect
classes.description:
A configuration of effects that defines the firework when exploded
which can be used in the launch firework effect.
See the firework effect expression for detailed patterns.
classes.examples:
launch flickering trailing burst firework colored blue and green at player
launch trailing flickering star colored purple, yellow, blue, green and red fading to pink at target entity
launch ball large colored red, purple and white fading to light green and black at player's location with duration 1

classes.description: The type of a fireworkeffect.

classes.name: Function
classes.description:
A function loaded by Skript.
This can be executed (with arguments) and may return a result.
classes.examples:
run {_function} with arguments 1 and true
set {_result} to the result of {_function}

classes.name: Game Mode

classes.name: Inventory
classes.description:
An inventory of a player or block. Inventories have many effects and conditions regarding the items contained.
An inventory has a fixed amount of slots which represent a specific place in the inventory, e.g. the helmet slot for players (Please note that slot support is still very limited but will be improved eventually).

classes.name: Item
patterns: [<number> [of]] <alias> [of <enchantment> <level>], Where <alias> must be an alias that represents exactly one item (i.e cannot be a general alias like 'sword' or 'plant')
classes.description:
An item, e.g. a stack of torches, a furnace, or a wooden sword of sharpness 2. Unlike item type an item can only represent exactly one item (e.g. an upside-down cobblestone stair facing west), while an item type can represent a whole range of items (e.g. any cobble stone stairs regardless of direction).
You don't usually need this type except when you want to make a command that only accepts an exact item.
Please note that currently 'material' is exactly the same as 'item', i.e. can have an amount & enchantments.
classes.examples:
set {_item} to type of the targeted block
{_item} is a torch

classes.name: Item Type
classes.description:
An item type is an alias, e.g. 'a pickaxe', 'all plants', etc., and can result in different items when added to an inventory, and unlike items they are well suited for checking whether an inventory contains a certain item or whether a certain item is of a certain type.
An item type can also have one or more enchantments with or without a specific level defined, and can optionally start with 'all' or 'every' to make this item type represent all types that the alias represents, including data ranges.
classes.examples:
give 4 torches to the player
add all slabs to the inventory of the block
player's tool is a diamond sword of sharpness
remove a pickaxes of fortune 4 from {stored items::*}
set {_item} to 10 of every upside-down stair
block is dirt or farmland

classes.name: Living Entity
patterns: see entity, but ignore inanimate objects
classes.description: A living entity, i.e. a mob or player, not inanimate entities like projectiles or dropped items.
classes.examples:
spawn 5 powered creepers
shoot a zombie from the creeper

classes.name: Location
classes.description: A location in a world. Locations are world-specific and even store a direction, e.g. if you save a location and later teleport to it you will face the exact same direction you did when you saved the location.

classes.name: Loot Context
classes.description:
Represents additional information a loot table can use to modify its generated loot.

Some loot tables will require some values (i.e. looter, location, looted entity) in a loot context when generating loot whereas others may not.
For example, the loot table of a simple dungeon chest will only require a location, whereas the loot table of a cow will require a looting player, looted entity, and location.
You can find more information about this in https://minecraft.wiki/w/Loot_context

classes.name: Loot Table
classes.description:
Loot tables represent what items should be in naturally generated containers, what items should be dropped when killing a mob, or what items can be fished.
You can find more information about this in https://minecraft.wiki/w/Loot_table

classes.name: Metadata Holder
classes.description: Something that can hold metadata (e.g. an entity or block)
classes.examples: set metadata value "super cool" of player to true

classes.name: Minecraft Tag
classes.description: A tag that classifies a material, or entity.

classes.name: Money
patterns: <number> $ or $ <number>, where '$' is your server's currency, e.g. '10 rupees' or '£5.00'
classes.description: A certain amount of money. Please note that this differs from numbers as it includes a currency symbol or name, but usually the two are interchangeable, e.g. you can both add 100$ to the player's balance and add 100 to the player's balance.
classes.examples:
add 10£ to the player's account
remove Fr. 9.95 from the player's money
set the victim's money to 0
increase the attacker's balance by the level of the victim * 100

classes.name: Moon Phase
patterns: last quarter, waning crescent, waxing gibbous, full moon, waning gibbous, waxing crescent, new moon, first quarter
classes.description: Represents the phase of a moon.

classes.name: Node
classes.description:
A node (entry) from a script config file.
This may have navigable children.

classes.name: Number
patterns: [-]###[.###] [[in ](rad[ian][s]|deg[ree][s])] (any amount of digits; very large numbers will be truncated though)
classes.description:
A number, e.g. 2.5, 3, -9812454, 30 degrees or 3.14 radians.
Please note that many expressions only need integers, i.e. will discard any fractional parts of any numbers without producing an error.
Radians will be converted to degrees.
classes.examples:
set the player's health to 5.5
set {_temp} to 2*{_temp} - 2.5
set {_angle} to 3.14 in radians # will be converted to degrees

classes.name: Object
classes.description: The supertype of all types, meaning that if %object% is used in e.g. a condition it will accept all kinds of expressions.

classes.name: Offline Player
patterns: Parsing an offline player as a player (online) will return nothing (none), for that case you would need to parse as offlineplayer which only returns nothing (none) if player doesn't exist in Minecraft databases (name not taken) otherwise it will return the player regardless of their online status.
classes.description: A player that is possibly offline. See player for more information. Please note that while all effects and conditions that require a player can be used with an offline player as well, they will not work if the player is not actually online.
classes.examples: set {_p} to "Notch" parsed as an offlineplayer # returns Notch even if they're offline

classes.name: Player
patterns: Parsing an offline player as a player (online) will return nothing (none), for that case you would need to parse as offlineplayer which only returns nothing (none) if player doesn't exist in Minecraft databases (name not taken) otherwise it will return the player regardless of their online status.
classes.description:
A player. Depending on whether a player is online or offline several actions can be performed with them, though you won't get any errors when using effects that only work if the player is online (e.g. changing their inventory) on an offline player.
You have two possibilities to use players as command arguments: <player> and <offline player>. The first requires that the player is online and also accepts only part of the name, while the latter doesn't require that the player is online, but the player's name has to be entered exactly.
classes.examples:
set {_p} to "Notch" parsed as a player # returns &amp;amp;amp;lt;none&amp;amp;amp;gt; unless Notch is actually online or starts with Notch like Notchan
set {_p} to "N" parsed as a player # returns Notch if Notch is online because their name starts with 'N' (case insensitive) however, it would return nothing if no player whose name starts with 'N' is online.

apply potion of speed 2 to the player for 60 seconds
remove invisibility from the victim

classes.name: Projectile
patterns: arrow, fireball, snowball, thrown potion, etc.
classes.description: A projectile, e.g. an arrow, snowball or thrown potion.
classes.examples:
projectile is a snowball
shoot an arrow at speed 5 from the player

classes.name: Quaternion
classes.description: Quaternions are four dimensional vectors, often used for representing rotations.

classes.name: Queue
classes.description: A queued list of values. Entries are removed from a queue when they are queried.
classes.examples:
set {queue} to a new queue
add "hello" to {queue}
broadcast the 1st element of {queue}

classes.name: Quit Reason
patterns: disconnected, erroneous state, kicked, quit, timed out, erroneous
classes.description: Represents a quit reason from a player quit server event.

classes.name: Region
classes.description:
A region of a regions plugin. Skript currently supports WorldGuard, Factions, GriefPrevention and PreciousStones.
Please note that some regions plugins do not have named regions, some use numerical ids to identify regions, and some may have regions with the same name in different worlds, thus using regions like "region name" in scripts may or may not work.

classes.name: Resource Pack State
patterns: discarded, refused, rejected, failed reload, accepted, failed, failed to reload, failed to download, downloaded, successfully loaded, accept, fail, successfully load, refuse, declined, successfully install, success, reject, decline, successfully installed, download fail, invalid url
classes.description: The state in a resource pack request response event.

classes.name: Script
classes.description:
A script loaded by Skript.
Disabled scripts will report as being empty since their content has not been loaded.

classes.name: Server Icon
classes.description: A server icon that was loaded using the load server icon effect.

classes.name: Slot
classes.description:
Represents a single slot of an inventory. Notable slots are the armour slots and furnace slots.
The most important property that distinguishes a slot from an item is its ability to be changed, e.g. it can be set, deleted, enchanted, etc. (Some item expressions can be changed as well, e.g. items stored in variables. For that matter: slots are never saved to variables, only the items they represent at the time when the variable is set).
Please note that tool can be regarded a slot, but it can actually change it's position, i.e. doesn't represent always the same slot.
classes.examples:
set tool of player to dirt
delete helmet of the victim
set the color of the player's tool to green
enchant the player's chestplate with projectile protection 5

classes.name: Sound Category
patterns: hostile creatures category, speech category, records category, friendly creature category, noteblock category, hostile creature category, note block category, voice category, ambient category, noteblocks category, note blocks category, weather category, block category, friendly mob category, jukebox category, hostile mob category, master category, master volume category, hostile category, record category, blocks category, environment category, jukeboxes category, player category, players category, hostile mobs category, friendly mobs category, music category, friendly creatures category, neutral category
classes.description: The category of a sound, they are used for sound options of Minecraft. See the play sound and stop sound effects.

classes.name: Spawn Reason
patterns: dispense egg, egg, village defense, ocelot baby, silverfish trap, village invading, trap, dispensing egg, shoulder, drowned, metamorphosis, lightning, silverfish reveal, spell, built iron golem, natural, trial mob spawner, village invasion, frozen, mount, build wither, built wither, iron golem defense, ender pearl, creature spawner, reinforcements, build snowman, build iron golem, breeding, raid, ominous item spawner, infection, customized, potion effect, spawn egg, jockey, beehive, default, golem defense, patrol, slime split, infected, sheared, mob spawner, nether portal, trial spawner, shear, perching, custom, built snowman, chunk generation, breed, command, duplication, explosion, spawner, cured, enchantment, trial creature spawner, customised, piglin zombification
classes.description: The spawn reason in a spawn event.

classes.name: Teleport Cause
patterns: bed exit, nether portal, ender gateway, exiting bed, chorus fruit, ender portal, command, unknown, plugin, dismounted, ender pearl, spectator, spectate, end gateway, chorus, exit bed, gateway, dismount, end portal
classes.description: The teleport cause in a teleport event.

classes.name: Teleport Flag
patterns: passengers, xyz velocity, z velocity, yaw velocity, inventory, pitch velocity, vehicle, opened inventory, open inventory, x velocity, passenger, pitch and yaw velocity, yaw and pitch velocity, directional velocity, y velocity
classes.description: Teleport Flags are settings to retain during a teleport.

classes.name: Text
classes.description:
Text is simply text, i.e. a sequence of characters, which can optionally contain expressions which will be replaced with a meaningful representation (e.g. %player% will be replaced with the player's name).
Because scripts are also text, you have to put text into double quotes to tell Skript which part of the line is an effect/expression and which part is the text.
Please read the article on Texts and Variable Names to learn more.
classes.examples:
broadcast "Hello World!"
message "Hello %player%"
message "The id of ""%type of tool%"" is %id of tool%."

classes.name: Time
classes.description:
A time is a point in a minecraft day's time (i.e. ranges from 0:00 to 23:59), which can vary per world.
See date and timespan for the other time types of Skript.

classes.name: Timeperiod
classes.description:
A period of time between two times. Mostly useful since you can use this to test for whether it's day, night, dusk or dawn in a specific world.
This type might be removed in the future as you can use 'time of world is between x and y' as a replacement.

classes.name: Timespan
classes.description:
A timespan is a difference of two different dates or times, e.g '10 minutes'. Timespans are always displayed as real life time, but can be defined as minecraft time, e.g. '5 minecraft days and 12 hours'.
NOTE: Months always have the value of 30 days, and years of 365 days.
See date and time for the other time types of Skript.
classes.examples:
every 5 minecraft days:
wait a minecraft second and 5 ticks
every 10 mc days and 12 hours:
halt for 12.7 irl minutes, 12 hours and 120.5 seconds

classes.name: Transform Reason
patterns: infection, magma slime split, villager infection, tadpole metamorphosis, drowning, creeper super charge, unknown, split, tadpole converting, metamorphosis, skeleton converting to stray, lightning, slime split, entity drowning, slime splitting, zombie drowning, zombie curing, skeleton freeze, entity freezing, zombie converting to drowned, curing, entity freeze, skeleton freezing, mooshroom shear, zombie cure, tadpole converting to frog, mooshroom shearing, magma slime splitting, piglin zombification
classes.description: Represents a transform reason of an entity transform event.

classes.name: Tree Type
patterns: [any] <general tree/mushroom type>, e.g. tree/any jungle tree/etc.
<specific tree/mushroom species>, e.g. red mushroom/small jungle tree/big regular tree/etc.
classes.description: A tree type represents a tree species or a huge mushroom species. These can be generated in a world with the generate tree effect.
classes.examples:
grow any regular tree at the block
grow a huge red mushroom above the block

classes.name: Type
patterns: See the type name patterns of all types - including this one
classes.description:
Represents a type, e.g. number, object, item type, location, block, world, entity type, etc.
This is mostly used for expressions like 'event-<type>', '<type>-argument', 'loop-<type>', etc., e.g. event-world, number-argument and loop-player.
classes.examples:
{variable} is a number # check whether the variable contains a number, e.g. -1 or 5.5
{variable} is a type # check whether the variable contains a type, e.g. number or player
{variable} is an object # will always succeed if the variable is set as everything is an object, even types.
disable PvP in the event-world
kill the loop-entity

classes.name: UUID
classes.description:
UUIDs are unique identifiers that ensure things can be reliably distinguished from each other. They are generated in a way that makes it practically impossible for duplicates to occur.
Read more about UUIDs and how they are used in Minecraft in the wiki entry about UUIDs.

classes.name: Unleash Reason
patterns: player unleashed, distance, unleashed by player, player unleash, holder (gone|disappeared), unknown
classes.description: Represents an unleash reason of an unleash event.

classes.name: Vector
classes.description: Vector is a collection of numbers. In Minecraft, 3D vectors are used to express velocities of entities.

classes.name: Vehicle
classes.description: Represents a vehicle.

classes.name: Villager Profession
patterns: armorer, armorer profession, butcher, butcher profession, cartographer, cartographer profession, cleric, cleric profession, farmer, farmer profession, fisherman, fisherman profession, fletcher, fletcher profession, leatherworker, leatherworker profession, librarian, librarian profession, mason, mason profession, nitwit, nitwit profession, no profession, none, none profession, shepherd, shepherd profession, toolsmith, toolsmith profession, unemployed, weaponsmith, weaponsmith profession
classes.description: Represents the different professions of villagers.

classes.name: Villager Type
patterns: desert, jungle, plains, savanna, snow, swamp, taiga
classes.description: Represents the different types of villagers. These are usually the biomes a villager can be from.

classes.name: Visual Effect
patterns: smoke, potion break, ender signal, mobspawner flames, arrow particles, jumping rabbit, hurt, wolf smoke, wolf hearts, wolf shaking, sheep eating, iron golem offering rose, witch magic, zombie turning to a villager, firework explosion, love hearts, squid rotation reset, entity poof, guardian target, block with shield, shield break, armor stand hit, hurt by thorns, iron golem sheathing rose, resurrection by totem, hurt by drowning, hurt by explosion, poof, large explosion, explosion emitter, firework, bubble, splash, water wake, underwater, critical hit, enchanted hit, smoke, large smoke, effect, instant effect, entity effect, witch, dripping water, dripping lava, angry villager, happy villager, mycelium, note, portal, enchant, flame, lava pop, cloud, dust, snowball, slime, heart, item, block, rain, elder guardian, dragon breath, end rod, damage indicator, sweep attack, falling dust, totem of undying, spit, squid ink, bubble pop, current down, bubble column up, nautilus, dolphin, sneeze, campfire cosy smoke, campfire signal smoke, composter, flash, falling lava, landing lava, falling water, dripping honey, falling honey, landing honey, falling nectar, soul fire flame, ash, crimson spore, warped spore, soul, dripping obsidian tear, falling obsidian tear, landing obsidian tear, reverse portal, white ash, dust color transition, vibration, falling spore blossom, spore blossom air, small flame, snowflake, dripping dripstone lava, falling dripstone lava, dripping dripstone water, falling dripstone water, glow squid ink, glow, wax on, wax off, electric spark, scrape, sonic boom, sculk soul, sculk charge, sculk charge pop, shriek, cherry leaves, egg crack, dust plume, white smoke, gust, small gust, large gust emitter, small gust emitter, trial spawner detection, ominous trial spawner detection, vault connection, infested, cobweb, dust pillar, ominous spawning, raid omen, block marker
classes.description: A visible effect, e.g. particles.
classes.examples:
show wolf hearts on the clicked wolf
play mob spawner flames at the targeted block to the player

classes.name: Weather Type
classes.description: The weather types sunny, rainy, and thundering.
classes.examples:
is raining
is sunny in the player's world
message "It is %weather in the argument's world% in %world of the argument%"

classes.name: Wolf Variant
patterns: ashen, black, chestnut, pale, rusty, snowy, spotted, striped, woods
classes.description:
Represents the variant of a wolf entity.
NOTE: Minecraft namespaces are supported, ex: 'minecraft:ashen'.

classes.name: World
classes.description: One of the server's worlds. Worlds can be put into scripts by surrounding their name with double quotes, e.g. "world_nether", but this might not work reliably as text uses the same syntax.

classes.name: World Environment
patterns: normal, nether, the end, the overworld, custom, the nether, end, overworld
classes.description: Represents the environment of a world.

conditions.name: Alphanumeric
conditions.description: Checks if the given string is alphanumeric.
conditions.examples:
if the argument is not alphanumeric:
send "Invalid name!"

conditions.name: Bell Is Resonating
conditions.description:
Checks to see if a bell is currently resonating.
A bell will start resonating five game ticks after being rung, and will continue to resonate for 40 game ticks.
conditions.examples: target block is resonating

conditions.name: Bell Is Ringing
conditions.description: Checks to see if a bell is currently ringing. A bell typically rings for 50 game ticks.
conditions.examples: target block is ringing

conditions.name: Can Age
conditions.description: Checks whether or not an entity will be able to age/grow up.
conditions.examples:
on breeding:
entity can't age
broadcast "An immortal has been born!" to player

conditions.name: Can Breed
conditions.description: Checks whether or not a living entity can be bred.
conditions.examples:
on right click on living entity:
event-entity can't breed
send "Turns out %event-entity% is not breedable. Must be a Skript user!" to player

conditions.name: Can Build
conditions.description:
Tests whether a player is allowed to build at a certain location.
This condition requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
conditions.examples:
command /setblock &lt;material&gt;:
description: set the block at your crosshair to a different type
trigger:
player cannot build at the targeted block:
message "You do not have permission to change blocks there!"
stop
set the targeted block to argument

conditions.name: Can Fly
conditions.description: Whether a player is allowed to fly.
conditions.examples: player can fly

conditions.name: Can Hold
patterns: %inventories% (can(no|')t hold|(ha(s|ve) not|ha(s|ve)n't|do[es]n't have) [enough] space (for|to hold)) %item types%
conditions.description: Tests whether a player or a chest can hold the given item.
conditions.examples:
block can hold 200 cobblestone
player has enough space for 64 feathers

conditions.name: Can Pick Up Items
patterns: %living entities% can pick([ ]up items| items up)
%living entities% (can't|cannot|can not) pick([ ]up items| items up)
conditions.description: Whether living entities are able to pick up items off the ground or not.
conditions.examples:
if player can pick items up:
send "You can pick up items!" to player

on drop:
if player can't pick up items:
send "Be careful, you won't be able to pick that up!" to player

conditions.name: Can See
conditions.description: Checks whether the given players can see the provided entities.
conditions.examples:
if sender can't see the player-argument:
message "who dat?"

if the player can see the last spawned entity:
message "hello there!"

conditions.name: Can See Chat Colors
conditions.description: Checks whether a player can see chat colors.
conditions.examples:
if player can see chat colors:
send "Find the red word in <red>this<reset> message."
else:
send "You cannot partake in finding the colored word."

conditions.name: Can See Messages
patterns: %player% can see all messages [in chat]
%player% can only see (commands|system messages) [in chat]
%player% can('t|[ ]not) see all messages [in chat]
%player% can('t|[ ]not) only see (commands|system messages) [in chat]
conditions.description: Checks whether a player can see specific message types in chat.
conditions.examples:
if player can see all messages:
send "You can see all messages."
if player can only see commands:
send "This game doesn't work with commands-only chat."
if player can't see any messages:
send action bar "Server shutting down in 5 minutes!"

conditions.name: Chance
conditions.description:
A condition that randomly succeeds or fails.
Valid values are between 0% and 100%, or if the percent sign is omitted between 0 and 1.
conditions.examples:
chance of 50%:
drop a diamond
chance of {chance}% # {chance} between 0 and 100
chance of {chance} # {chance} between 0 and 1

conditions.name: Comparison
patterns: [(neither)] %objects% ((is|are)[(n't| not| neither)] (greater|more|higher|bigger|larger|above) [than] or (equal to|the same as)|>=) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% ((is|are)[(n't| not| neither)] (less|smaller|lower|below) [than] or (equal to|the same as)|<=) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (is not|are not|isn't|aren't) between %objects% and %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (was|were)[(n't| not| neither)] (greater|more|higher|bigger|larger|above) [than] or (equal to|the same as) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (was|were)[(n't| not| neither)] (less|smaller|lower|below) [than] or (equal to|the same as) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (was not|were not|wasn't|weren't) between %objects% and %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (will be|(will (not|neither) be|won't be)) ((greater|more|higher|bigger|larger) than|above) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (will be|(will (not|neither) be|won't be)) (greater|more|higher|bigger|larger|above) [than] or (equal to|the same as) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (will be|(will (not|neither) be|won't be)) ((less|smaller|lower) than|below) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (will be|(will (not|neither) be|won't be)) (less|smaller|lower|below) [than] or (equal to|the same as) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% ((will (not|neither) be|won't be)|(isn't|aren't|is not|are not) (turning|changing) [in]to) [equal to] %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (will be [(equal to|the same as)]|(is|are) (turning|changing) [in]to) %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% will be between %objects% and %objects%
[(neither)] %objects% (will not be|won't be) between %objects% and %objects%
conditions.description:
A very general condition, it simply compares two values. Usually you can only compare for equality (e.g. block is/isn't of <type>), but some values can also be compared using greater than/less than. In that case you can also test for whether an object is between two others.
Note: This is the only element where not all patterns are shown. It has actually another two sets of similar patters, but with (was|were) or will be instead of (is|are) respectively, which check different time states of the first expression.
conditions.examples:
the clicked block is a stone slab or a double stone slab
time in the player's world is greater than 8:00
the creature is not an enderman or an ender dragon

conditions.name: Contains
patterns: %inventories% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have %item types% [in [(the[ir]|his|her|its)] inventory]
%inventories/texts/objects% contain[s] %item types/texts/objects%
%inventories/texts/objects% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) contain %item types/texts/objects%
conditions.description: Checks whether an inventory contains an item, a text contains another piece of text, a container contains something, or a list (e.g. {list variable::*} or 'drops') contains another object.
conditions.examples:
block contains 20 cobblestone
player has 4 flint and 2 iron ingots
{list::*} contains 5

conditions.name: Damage Cause
conditions.description: Tests what kind of damage caused a damage event. Refer to the Damage Cause type for a list of all possible causes.
conditions.examples:
# make players use their potions of fire resistance whenever they take any kind of fire damage
on damage:
damage was caused by lava, fire or burning
victim is a player
victim has a potion of fire resistance
cancel event
apply fire resistance to the victim for 30 seconds
remove 1 potion of fire resistance from the victim
# prevent mobs from dropping items under certain circumstances
on death:
entity is not a player
damage wasn't caused by a block explosion, an attack, a projectile, a potion, fire, burning, thorns or poison
clear drops

conditions.name: Do Respawn Anchors Work
patterns: respawn anchors [do[(n't| not)]] work in %worlds%
conditions.description: Checks whether or not respawn anchors work in a world.
conditions.examples: respawn anchors work in world "world_nether"

conditions.name: Egg Will Hatch
conditions.description: Whether the egg will hatch in a Player Egg Throw event.
conditions.examples:
on player egg throw:
if an entity won't hatch:
send "Better luck next time!" to the player

conditions.name: Entity Is Sheared
conditions.description: Checks whether entities are sheared. This condition only works on cows, sheep and snowmen for versions below 1.19.4.
conditions.examples:
if targeted entity of player is sheared:
send "This entity has nothing left to shear!" to player

conditions.name: Entity is Wet
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is wet or not (in water, rain or a bubble column).
conditions.examples: if player is wet:

conditions.name: Entity is in Liquid
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is in rain, lava, water or a bubble column.
conditions.examples:
if player is in rain:
if player is in water:
player is in lava:
player is in bubble column

conditions.name: Event Cancelled
conditions.description: Checks whether or not the event is cancelled.
conditions.examples:
on click:
if event is cancelled:
broadcast "no clicks allowed!"

conditions.name: Exists/Is Set
conditions.description: Checks whether a given expression or variable is set.
conditions.examples:
{teams::%player's uuid%::preferred-team} is not set
on damage:
projectile exists
broadcast "%attacker% used a %projectile% to attack %victim%!"

conditions.name: Fishing Lure Applied
conditions.description: Checks if the lure enchantment is applied to the current fishing event.
conditions.examples:
on fishing line cast:
if lure enchantment bonus is applied:
cancel event

conditions.name: Has AI
patterns: %living entities% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have (ai|artificial intelligence)
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity has AI.
conditions.examples: target entity has ai

conditions.name: Has Chat Filtering
conditions.description: Checks whether a player has chat filtering enabled.
conditions.examples:
if player doesn't have chat filtering enabled:
send "<gray>This server may contain mature chat messages. You have been warned!" to player

conditions.name: Has Client Weather
conditions.description: Checks whether the given players have a custom client weather
conditions.examples:
if the player has custom weather:
message "Your custom weather is %player's weather%"

conditions.name: Has Custom Model Data
patterns: %item types% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have [custom] model data
conditions.description: Check if an item has a custom model data tag
conditions.examples: player's tool has custom model data

conditions.name: Has Glowing Text
patterns: %blocks/item types% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have glowing text
conditions.description: Checks whether a sign (either a block or an item) has glowing text
conditions.examples: if target block has glowing text

conditions.name: Has Item Cooldown
patterns: %players% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have [([an] item|a)] cooldown (on|for) %item types%
%players% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have %item types% on [(item|a)] cooldown
conditions.description: Check whether a cooldown is active on the specified material for a specific player.
conditions.examples:
if player has player's tool on cooldown:
send "You can't use this item right now. Wait %item cooldown of player's tool for player%"

conditions.name: Has Item Tooltips
patterns: [the] [entire|additional] tool[ ]tip[s] of %item types% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) (shown|hidden)
conditions.description:
Whether the entire or additional tooltip of an item is shown or hidden.
The 'entire tooltip' is what shows to the player when they hover an item (i.e. name, lore, etc.).
The 'additional tooltip' hides certain information from certain items (potions, maps, books, fireworks, and banners).
conditions.examples:
send true if entire tooltip of player's tool is shown
if additional tooltip of {_item} is hidden:

conditions.name: Has Line of Sight
patterns: %living entities% (has|have) [a] [direct] line of sight to %entities/locations%
%living entities% does(n't| not) have [a] [direct] line of sight to %entities/locations%
%living entities% (has|have) no [direct] line of sight to %entities/locations%
conditions.description: Checks whether living entities have an unobstructed line of sight to other entities or locations.
conditions.examples:
player has direct line of sight to location 5 blocks to the right of player
victim has line of sight to attacker
player has no line of sight to location 100 blocks in front of player

conditions.name: Has Loot Table
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity or block has a loot table. The loot tables of chests will be deleted when the chest is opened or broken.
conditions.examples:
set event-block to chest
if event-block has a loot table:
# this will never happen, because it doesn't have a loot table.

set loot table of event-block to "minecraft:chests/simple_dungeon"

if event-block has a loot table:
# this will happen, because it now has a loot table.

conditions.name: Has Metadata
patterns: %metadata holders% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have metadata [(value|tag)[s]] %texts%
conditions.description: Checks whether a metadata holder has a metadata tag.
conditions.examples: if player has metadata value "healer":

conditions.name: Has Permission
patterns: %command senders% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have [the] permission[s] %texts%
conditions.description: Test whether a player has a certain permission.
conditions.examples:
player has permission "skript.tree"
victim has the permission "admin":
send "You're attacking an admin!" to attacker

conditions.name: Has Played Before
patterns: %offline players% (has not|hasn't|have not|haven't|did not|didn't) [(already|yet)] play[ed] [on (this|the) server] (before|already|yet)
conditions.description: Checks whether a player has played on this server before. You can also use on first join if you want to make triggers for new players.
conditions.examples:
player has played on this server before
player hasn't played before

conditions.name: Has Potion
patterns: %living entities% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have potion[s] [effect[s]] %potion effect types%
conditions.description: Checks whether the given living entities have specific potion effects.
conditions.examples:
if player has potion speed:
send "You are sonic!"

if all players have potion effects speed and haste:
broadcast "You are ready to MINE!"

conditions.name: Has Resource Pack
patterns: %players% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have [a] resource pack [(loaded|installed)]
conditions.description: Checks whether the given players have a server resource pack loaded. Please note that this can't detect player's own resource pack, only the resource pack that sent by the server.
conditions.examples: if the player has a resource pack loaded:

conditions.name: Has Scoreboard Tag
patterns: %entities% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have [the] score[ ]board tag[s] %texts%
conditions.description: Checks whether the given entities has the given scoreboard tags.
conditions.examples: if the targeted armor stand has the scoreboard tag "test tag":

conditions.name: Ignition Process
patterns: [creeper[s]] %living entities% ((is|are)|(isn't|is not|aren't|are not)) going to explode
[creeper[s]] %living entities% ((is|are)|(isn't|is not|aren't|are not)) in the (ignition|explosion) process
creeper[s] %living entities% ((is|are)|(isn't|is not|aren't|are not)) ignited
conditions.description: Checks if a creeper is going to explode.
conditions.examples:
if the last spawned creeper is going to explode:
loop all players in radius 3 of the last spawned creeper
send "RUN!!!" to the loop-player

conditions.name: In The Past/Future
conditions.description:
Checks whether a date is in the past or future.
Note that using the 'now' expression will not be in the past or future when used directly in the condition.
conditions.examples:
set {_date} to now
wait 5 seconds
if {_date} is in the past:
# this will be true

if now is in the future:
# this will be false

set {_dates::*} to 1 day from now, 12 days from now, and 1 year from now
if {_dates::*} are in the future:
# this will be true
if {_dates::*} have passed:
# this will be false

conditions.name: Is Adult
conditions.description: Checks whether or not a living entity is an adult.
conditions.examples:
on drink:
event-entity is not an adult
kill event-entity

conditions.name: Is Alive
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is alive. Works for non-living entities too.
conditions.examples:
if {villager-buddy::%player's uuid%} is not dead:

on shoot:
while the projectile is alive:

conditions.name: Is Baby
conditions.description: Checks whether or not a living entity is a baby.
conditions.examples:
on drink:
event-entity is a baby
kill event-entity

conditions.name: Is Banned
conditions.description: Checks whether a player or IP is banned.
conditions.examples:
player is banned
victim is not IP-banned
"127.0.0.1" is banned

conditions.name: Is Bed/Anchor Spawn
conditions.description: Checks what the respawn location of a player in the respawn event is.
conditions.examples:
on respawn:
the respawn location is a bed
broadcast "%player% is respawning in their bed! So cozy!"

conditions.name: Is Block
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is a block.
conditions.examples:
player's held item is a block
{list::*} are blocks

conditions.name: Is Block Redstone Powered
conditions.description: Checks if a block is indirectly or directly powered by redstone
conditions.examples:
if clicked block is redstone powered:
send "This block is well-powered by redstone!"
if clicked block is indirectly redstone powered:
send "This block is indirectly redstone powered."

conditions.name: Is Blocking
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is blocking with their shield.
conditions.examples:
on damage of player:
victim is blocking
damage attacker by 0.5 hearts

conditions.name: Is Burning
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is on fire, e.g. a zombie due to being in sunlight, or any entity after falling into lava.
conditions.examples:
# increased attack against burning targets
victim is burning:
increase damage by 2

conditions.name: Is Charged
conditions.description: Checks if a creeper, wither, or wither skull is charged (powered).
conditions.examples:
if the last spawned creeper is charged:
broadcast "A charged creeper is at %location of last spawned creeper%"

conditions.name: Is Climbing
conditions.description: Whether a living entity is climbing, such as a spider up a wall or a player on a ladder.
conditions.examples:
spawn a spider at location of spawn
wait a second
if the last spawned spider is climbing:
message"The spider is now climbing!"

conditions.name: Is Conditional
conditions.description: Checks whether a command block is conditional or not.
conditions.examples:
if {_block} is conditional:
make {_block} unconditional

conditions.name: Is Custom Name Visible
patterns: custom name of %entities% (isn't|is not|are not|aren't) visible
conditions.description: Checks if an entity's custom name is visible.
conditions.examples: send true if target's custom name is visible

conditions.name: Is Edible
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is edible.
conditions.examples:
steak is edible
player's tool is edible

conditions.name: Is Empty
patterns: %inventories/slots/texts/numbered thing% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) empty
conditions.description: Checks whether an inventory, an inventory slot, a queue, or a text is empty.
conditions.examples: player's inventory is empty

conditions.name: Is Enchanted
patterns: %item types% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) enchanted [with %enchantment type%]
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is enchanted.
conditions.examples:
tool of the player is enchanted with efficiency 2
helm, chestplate, leggings or boots are enchanted

conditions.name: Is Evenly Divisible By
patterns: %numbers% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) evenly divisible by %number%
%numbers% can be evenly divided by %number%
%numbers% (can't|can[ ]not) be evenly divided by %number%
conditions.description: Check if a number is evenly divisible by another number.
conditions.examples:
if 5 is evenly divisible by 5:
if 11 cannot be evenly divided by 10:

conditions.name: Is Fire Resistant
patterns: %item types% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) (fire resistant|resistant to fire)
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is fire resistant.
conditions.examples:
if player's tool is fire resistant:
if {_items::*} aren't resistant to fire:

conditions.name: Is Fish Hook in Open Water
conditions.description:
Checks whether the fish hook is in open water.
Open water is defined by a 5x4x5 area of water, air and lily pads. If in open water, treasure items may be caught.
conditions.examples:
on fish catch:
if fish hook is in open water:
send "You will catch a shark soon!"

conditions.name: Is Flammable
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is flammable.
conditions.examples:
wood is flammable
player's tool is flammable

conditions.name: Is Flying
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is flying.
conditions.examples: player is not flying

conditions.name: Is From A Mob Spawner
conditions.description: Checks if an entity was spawned from a mob spawner.
conditions.examples: send whether target is from a mob spawner

conditions.name: Is Frozen
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is frozen.
conditions.examples:
if player is frozen:
kill player

conditions.name: Is Fuel
conditions.description: Checks whether an item can be used as fuel in a furnace.
conditions.examples:
on right click on furnace:
if player's tool is not fuel:
send "Please hold a valid fuel item in your hand"
cancel event

conditions.name: Is Gliding
conditions.description: Checks whether a living entity is gliding.
conditions.examples: if player is gliding

conditions.name: Is Hand Raised
patterns: %living entities%'[s] [main] hand[s] (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) raised
[main] hand[s] of %living entities% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) raised
%living entities%'[s] off[ |-]hand[s] (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) raised
off[ |-]hand[s] of %living entities% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) raised
conditions.description:
Checks whether an entity has one or both of their hands raised.
Hands are raised when an entity is using an item (eg: blocking, drawing a bow, eating).
conditions.examples:
on damage of player:
if victim's main hand is raised:
drop player's tool at player
set player's tool to air

conditions.name: Is Holding
patterns: [%living entities%] ha(s|ve) %item types% in [main] hand
[%living entities%] (is|are) holding %item types% [in main hand]
[%living entities%] ha(s|ve) %item types% in off[(-| )]hand
[%living entities%] (is|are) holding %item types% in off[(-| )]hand
[%living entities%] (ha(s|ve) not|do[es]n't have) %item types% in [main] hand
[%living entities%] (is not|isn't) holding %item types% [in main hand]
[%living entities%] (ha(s|ve) not|do[es]n't have) %item types% in off[(-| )]hand
[%living entities%] (is not|isn't) holding %item types% in off[(-| )]hand
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is holding a specific item. Cannot be used with endermen, use 'entity is [not] an enderman holding <item type>' instead.
conditions.examples:
player is holding a stick
victim isn't holding a sword of sharpness

conditions.name: Is In Love
patterns: %living entities% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) in lov(e|ing) [state|mode]
conditions.description: Checks whether or not a living entity is in love.
conditions.examples:
on spawn of living entity:
if entity is in love:
broadcast "That was quick!"

conditions.name: Is Incendiary
patterns: %entities% ((is not|are not|isn't|aren't) incendiary|(does not|do not|doesn't|don't) cause[s] a[n] (incendiary|fiery) explosion)
conditions.description: Checks if an entity will create fire when it explodes. This condition is also usable in an explosion prime event.
conditions.examples:
on explosion prime:
if the explosion is fiery:
broadcast "A fiery explosive has been ignited!"

conditions.name: Is Infinite
conditions.description: Checks whether potion effects are infinite.
conditions.examples: all of the active potion effects of the player are infinite

conditions.name: Is Interactable
conditions.description: Checks wether or not a block is interactable.
conditions.examples:
on block break:
if event-block is interactable:
cancel event
send "You cannot break interactable blocks!"

conditions.name: Is Invisible
conditions.description: Checks whether a living entity is invisible.
conditions.examples: target entity is invisible

conditions.name: Is Invulnerable
conditions.description:
Checks whether an entity or a gamemode is invulnerable.
For gamemodes, Paper and Minecraft 1.20.6 are required
conditions.examples:
target entity is invulnerable

loop all gamemodes:
if loop-value is not invulnerable:
broadcast "the gamemode %loop-value% is vulnerable!"

conditions.name: Is Jumping
conditions.description: Checks whether a living entity is jumping. This condition does not work on players.
conditions.examples:
on spawn of zombie:
while event-entity is not jumping:
wait 5 ticks
push event-entity upwards

conditions.name: Is Leashed
conditions.description: Checks to see if an entity is currently leashed.
conditions.examples: target entity is leashed

conditions.name: Is Loaded
patterns: chunk [at] %number%, %number% (in|of) [world] %world% is[((n't| not))] loaded
conditions.description:
Checks whether a world, chunk or script is loaded.
'chunk at 1, 1' uses chunk coordinates, which are location coords divided by 16.
conditions.examples:
if chunk at {home::%player's uuid%} is loaded:
if chunk 1, 10 in world "world" is loaded:
if world("lobby") is loaded:
if script named "MyScript.sk" is loaded:

conditions.name: Is Lootable
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity or block is lootable. Lootables are entities or blocks that can have a loot table.
conditions.examples:
spawn a pig at event-location
set {_pig} to last spawned entity
if {_pig} is lootable:
set loot table of {_pig} to "minecraft:entities/cow"
# the pig will now drop the loot of a cow when killed, because it is indeed a lootable entity.
set block at event-location to chest
if block at event-location is lootable:
set loot table of block at event-location to "minecraft:chests/simple_dungeon"
# the chest will now generate the loot of a simple dungeon when opened, because it is indeed a lootable block.
set block at event-location to wool block
if block at event-location is lootable:
# uh oh, nothing will happen because a wool is not a lootable block.

conditions.name: Is Member/Owner of Region
patterns: %offline players% (is|are) ([a] member|[(the|an)] owner) of [[the] region] %regions%
%offline players% (is|are)(n't| not) ([a] member|[(the|an)] owner) of [[the] region] %regions%
conditions.description:
Checks whether a player is a member or owner of a particular region.
This condition requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
conditions.examples:
on region enter:
player is the owner of the region
message "Welcome back to %region%!"
send "%player% just entered %region%!" to all members of the region

conditions.name: Is Normalized
conditions.description: Checks whether a vector is normalized i.e. length of 1
conditions.examples: vector of player's location is normalized

conditions.name: Is Occluding
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is a block and completely blocks vision.
conditions.examples: player's tool is occluding

conditions.name: Is Online
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is online. The 'connected' pattern will return false once this player leaves the server, even if they rejoin. Be aware that using the 'connected' pattern with a variable will not have this special behavior. Use the direct event-player or other non-variable expression for best results.
conditions.examples:
player is online
player-argument is offline
while player is connected:
wait 60 seconds
send "hello!" to player

# The following will act like `{_player} is online`.
# Using variables with `is connected` will not behave the same as with non-variables.
while {_player} is connected:
broadcast "online!"
wait 1 tick

conditions.name: Is Operator
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is a server operator.
conditions.examples: player is an operator

conditions.name: Is Passable
conditions.description:
Checks whether a block is passable.
A block is passable if it has no colliding parts that would prevent players from moving through it.
Blocks like tall grass, flowers, signs, etc. are passable, but open doors, fence gates, trap doors, etc. are not because they still have parts that can be collided with.
conditions.examples: if player's targeted block is passable

conditions.name: Is Pathfinding
patterns: %living entities% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) pathfinding [to[wards] %living entity/location%]
conditions.description:
Checks whether living entities are pathfinding.
Can only be a living entity that is a Mob.
conditions.examples:
make {_entity} pathfind to {_location} at speed 2
while {_entity} is pathfinding
wait a second
launch flickering trailing burst firework colored red at location of {_entity}
subtract 10 from {defence::tower::health}
clear entity within {_entity}

conditions.name: Is Plugin Enabled
conditions.description:
Check if a plugin is enabled/disabled on the server.
Plugin names can be found in the plugin's 'plugin.yml' file or by using the '/plugins' command, they are NOT the name of the plugin's jar file.
When checking if a plugin is not enabled, this will return true if the plugin is either disabled or not on the server.
When checking if a plugin is disabled, this will return true if the plugin is on the server and is disabled.
conditions.examples:
if plugin "Vault" is enabled:
if plugin "WorldGuard" is not enabled:
if plugins "Essentials" and "Vault" are enabled:
if plugin "MyBrokenPlugin" is disabled:

conditions.name: Is Poisoned
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is poisoned.
conditions.examples:
player is poisoned:
cure the player from poison
message "You have been cured!"

conditions.name: Is Preferred Tool
patterns: %item types% (is|are) %blocks/block datas%'s preferred tool[s]
%item types% (is|are) [the|a] preferred tool[s] (for|of) %blocks/block datas%
%item types% (is|are)(n't| not) %blocks/block datas%'s preferred tool[s]
%item types% (is|are)(n't| not) [the|a] preferred tool[s] (for|of) %blocks/block datas%
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is the preferred tool for a block. A preferred tool is one that will drop the block's item when used. For example, a wooden pickaxe is a preferred tool for grass and stone blocks, but not for iron ore.
conditions.examples:
on left click:
event-block is set
if player's tool is the preferred tool for event-block:
break event-block naturally using player's tool
else:
cancel event

conditions.name: Is Pressing Key
patterns: %players% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) pressing %input keys%
%players% (wasn't|was not|weren't|were not) pressing %input keys%
conditions.description: Checks if a player is pressing a certain input key.
conditions.examples:
on player input:
if player is pressing forward movement key:
send "You are moving forward!"

conditions.name: Is Riding
conditions.description: Tests whether an entity is riding another or is in a vehicle.
conditions.examples: player is riding a saddled pig

conditions.name: Is Riptiding
conditions.description: Checks to see if an entity is currently using the Riptide enchantment.
conditions.examples: target entity is riptiding

conditions.name: Is Saddled
conditions.description:
Checks whether a given entity (horse or steerable) is saddled.
If 'properly' is used, this will only return true if the entity is wearing specifically a saddle item.
conditions.examples: send whether {_horse} is saddled

conditions.name: Is Script Loaded
conditions.description: Check if the current script, or another script, is currently loaded.
conditions.examples:
script is loaded
script "example.sk" is loaded

conditions.name: Is Silent
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is silent i.e. its sounds are disabled.
conditions.examples: target entity is silent

conditions.name: Is Sleeping
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is sleeping.
conditions.examples:
# cut your enemies' throats in their sleep >=)
on attack:
attacker is holding a sword
victim is sleeping
increase the damage by 1000

conditions.name: Is Slime Chunk
patterns: %chunk% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) ([a] slime chunk|slime chunks|slimey)
conditions.description:
Tests whether a chunk is a so-called slime chunk.
Slimes can generally spawn in the swamp biome and in slime chunks.
For more info, see the Minecraft wiki.
conditions.examples:
command /slimey:
trigger:
if chunk at player is a slime chunk:
send "Yeah, it is!"
else:
send "Nope, it isn't"

conditions.name: Is Sneaking
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is sneaking.
conditions.examples:
# prevent mobs from seeing sneaking players if they are at least 4 meters apart
on target:
target is sneaking
distance of target and the entity is bigger than 4
cancel the event

conditions.name: Is Solid
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is solid.
conditions.examples:
grass block is solid
player's tool isn't solid

conditions.name: Is Sprinting
conditions.description: Checks whether a player is sprinting.
conditions.examples: player is not sprinting

conditions.name: Is Stackable
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is stackable.
conditions.examples:
diamond axe is stackable
birch wood is stackable
torch is stackable

conditions.name: Is Swimming
conditions.description: Checks whether a living entity is swimming.
conditions.examples: player is swimming

conditions.name: Is Tagged
patterns: %item types/entities/entity types% (is|are) tagged (as|with) %minecraft tags%
%item types/entities/entity types% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) tagged (as|with) %minecraft tags%
conditions.description: Checks whether an item, block, entity, or entitydata is tagged with the given tag.
conditions.examples:
if player's tool is tagged with minecraft tag "enchantable/sharp_weapon":
enchant player's tool with sharpness 1

if all logs are tagged with tag "minecraft:logs"

conditions.name: Is Tameable
conditions.description: Check if an entity is tameable.
conditions.examples:
on damage:
if victim is tameable:
cancel event

conditions.name: Is Tamed
conditions.description: Check if a tameable entity is tamed (horse, parrot, cat, etc.).
conditions.examples:
send true if {_horse} is tamed
tame {_horse} if {_horse} is untamed

conditions.name: Is Ticking
conditions.description: Checks if an entity is ticking.
conditions.examples: send true if target is ticking

conditions.name: Is Transparent
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is transparent. Note that this condition may not work for all blocks, due to the transparency list used by Spigot not being completely accurate.
conditions.examples: player's tool is transparent.

conditions.name: Is Unbreakable
conditions.description: Checks whether an item is unbreakable.
conditions.examples:
if event-item is unbreakable:
send "This item is unbreakable!" to player
if tool of {_p} is breakable:
send "Your tool is breakable!" to {_p}

conditions.name: Is Using Experimental Feature
conditions.description: Checks whether a script is using an experimental feature by name.
conditions.examples:
the script is using "example feature"
on load:
if the script is using "example feature":
broadcast "You're using an experimental feature!"

conditions.name: Is Valid
conditions.description:
Checks whether something (an entity, a script, a config, etc.) is valid.
An invalid entity may have died or de-spawned for some other reason.
An invalid script reference may have been reloaded, moved or disabled since.
conditions.examples: if event-entity is valid

conditions.name: Is Wearing
patterns: %living entities% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) wearing %item types%
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is wearing some items (usually armor).
conditions.examples:
player is wearing an iron chestplate and iron leggings
player is wearing all diamond armour
target is wearing wolf armor

conditions.name: Is Whitelisted
conditions.description: Whether or not the server or a player is whitelisted, or the server is whitelist enforced.
conditions.examples:
if the player is whitelisted:
if the server is whitelisted:
if the server whitelist is enforced:

conditions.name: Is Within
conditions.description:
Whether a location is within something else. The "something" can be a block, an entity, a chunk, a world, or a cuboid formed by two other locations.
Note that using the is between condition will refer to a straight line between locations, while this condition will refer to the cuboid between locations.
conditions.examples:
if player's location is within {_loc1} and {_loc2}:
send "You are in a PvP zone!" to player

if player is in world("world"):
send "You are in the overworld!" to player

if attacker's location is inside of victim:
cancel event
send "Back up!" to attacker and victim

conditions.name: Is Within Radius
conditions.description: Checks whether a location is within a certain radius of another location.
conditions.examples:
on damage:
if attacker's location is within 10 blocks around {_spawn}:
cancel event
send "You can't PVP in spawn."

conditions.name: Is a Skript command
conditions.description: Checks whether a command/string is a custom Skript command.
conditions.examples:
# Example 1
on command:
command is a skript command

# Example 2
"sometext" is a skript command

conditions.name: Is of Type
patterns: %item stacks/entities% (is|are) of type[s] %item types/entity types%
%item stacks/entities% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) of type[s] %item types/entity types%
conditions.description: Checks whether an item or an entity is of the given type. This is mostly useful for variables, as you can use the general 'is' condition otherwise (e.g. 'victim is a creeper').
conditions.examples:
tool is of type {selected type}
victim is of type {villager type}

conditions.name: Is on Ground
conditions.description: Checks whether an entity is on ground.
conditions.examples: player is not on ground

conditions.name: Item Has Enchantment Glint Override
patterns: %item types% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have enchantment glint overrid(den|e)
conditions.description: Checks whether an item has the enchantment glint overridden, or is forced to glint or not.
conditions.examples:
if the player's tool has the enchantment glint override
send "Your tool has the enchantment glint override." to player

if {_item} is forced to glint:
send "This item is forced to glint." to player
else if {_item} is forced to not glint:
send "This item is forced to not glint." to player
else:
send "This item does not have any glint override." to player

conditions.name: Item Has Enchantment Glint Override
patterns: %item types% (isn't|is not|aren't|are not) forced to [not] glint
conditions.description: Checks whether an item has the enchantment glint overridden, or is forced to glint or not.
conditions.examples:
if the player's tool has the enchantment glint override
send "Your tool has the enchantment glint override." to player

if {_item} is forced to glint:
send "This item is forced to glint." to player
else if {_item} is forced to not glint:
send "This item is forced to not glint." to player
else:
send "This item does not have any glint override." to player

conditions.name: Leash Will Drop
conditions.description: Checks whether the leash item will drop during the leash detaching in an unleash event.
conditions.examples:
on unleash:
if the leash will drop:
prevent the leash from dropping
else:
allow the leash to drop

conditions.name: Left Handed
conditions.description:
Checks if living entities or players are left or right-handed. Armor stands are neither right nor left-handed.
Paper 1.17.1+ is required for non-player entities.
conditions.examples:
on damage of player:
if victim is left handed:
cancel event

conditions.name: Lid Is Open/Closed
conditions.description: Check to see whether lidded blocks (chests, shulkers, etc.) are open or closed.
conditions.examples:
if the lid of {_chest} is closed:
open the lid of {_block}

conditions.name: Matches
patterns: %texts% (partially match[es]|do[es](n't| not) partially match) %texts%
conditions.description: Checks whether the defined strings match the input regexes (Regular expressions).
conditions.examples:
on chat:
if message partially matches "\d":
send "Message contains a digit!"
if message doesn't match "[A-Za-z]+":
send "Message doesn't only contain letters!"

conditions.name: PvP
conditions.description: Checks the PvP state of a world.
conditions.examples:
PvP is enabled
PvP is disabled in "world"

conditions.name: Region Contains
conditions.description:
Checks whether a location is contained in a particular region.
This condition requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
conditions.examples:
player is in the region {regions::3}

on region enter:
region contains {flags.%world%.red}
message "The red flag is near!"

conditions.name: Resource Pack
conditions.description: Checks state of the resource pack in a resource pack request response event.
conditions.examples:
on resource pack response:
if the resource pack wasn't accepted:
kick the player due to "You have to install the resource pack to play in this server!"

conditions.name: Running Minecraft
conditions.description: Checks if current Minecraft version is given version or newer.
conditions.examples: running minecraft "1.14"

conditions.name: Starts/Ends With
conditions.description: Checks if a text starts or ends with another.
conditions.examples:
if the argument starts with "test" or "debug":
send "Stop!"

conditions.name: Text Display Has Drop Shadow
patterns: [[the] text of] %displays% (doesn't|does not|do not|don't) have [a] (drop|text) shadow
conditions.description: Returns whether the text of a display has drop shadow applied.
conditions.examples:
if {_display} has drop shadow:
remove drop shadow from the text of {_display}

conditions.name: Text Display Visible Through Blocks
conditions.description: Returns whether text displays can be seen through blocks or not.
conditions.examples:
if last spawned text display is visible through walls:
prevent last spawned text display from being visible through walls

conditions.name: Time
patterns: %date% (was|were)( more|(n't| not) less) than %time span% [ago]
%date% (was|were)((n't| not) more| less) than %time span% [ago]
conditions.description: Tests whether a given real time was more or less than some time span ago.
conditions.examples:
command /command-with-cooldown:
trigger:
{command::%player's uuid%::last-usage} was less than a minute ago:
message "Please wait a minute between uses of this command."
stop
set {command::%player's uuid%::last-usage} to now
# ... actual command trigger here ...

conditions.name: Will Consume Boosting Firework
conditions.description: Checks to see if the firework used in an 'elytra boost' event will be consumed.
conditions.examples:
on elytra boost:
if the used firework will be consumed:
prevent the used firework from being consume

effects.name: Action Bar
effects.description: Sends an action bar message to the given player(s).
effects.examples: send action bar "Hello player!" to player

effects.name: Allow / Prevent Leash Drop
effects.description: Allows or prevents the leash from being dropped in an unleash event.
effects.examples:
on unleash:
if player is not set:
prevent the leash from dropping
else if player is op:
allow the leash to drop

effects.name: Allow Aging
effects.description: Sets whether or not living entities will be able to age.
effects.examples:
on spawn of animal:
allow aging of entity

effects.name: Apply Bone Meal
effects.description: Applies bone meal to a crop, sapling, or composter
effects.examples: apply 3 bone meal to event-block

effects.name: Apply Fishing Lure
effects.description: Sets whether the lure enchantment should be applied, which reduces the wait time.
effects.examples:
on fishing line cast:
apply lure enchantment bonus

effects.name: Ban
patterns: ban [and kick] %texts/offline players% [(by reason of|because [of]|on account of|due to) %text%] [for %time span%]
ban [and kick] %players% by IP [(by reason of|because [of]|on account of|due to) %text%] [for %time span%]
IP(-| )ban [and kick] %players% [(by reason of|because [of]|on account of|due to) %text%] [for %time span%]
effects.description:
Bans or unbans a player or an IP address.
If a reason is given, it will be shown to the player when they try to join the server while banned.
A length of ban may also be given to apply a temporary ban. If it is absent for any reason, a permanent ban will be used instead.
We recommend that you test your scripts so that no accidental permanent bans are applied.

Note that banning people does not kick them from the server.
You can optionally use 'and kick' or consider using the kick effect after applying a ban.
effects.examples:
unban player
ban "127.0.0.1"
IP-ban the player because "he is an idiot"
ban player due to "inappropriate language" for 2 days
ban and kick player due to "inappropriate language" for 2 days

effects.name: Break Block
effects.description:
Breaks the block and spawns items as if a player had mined it
You can add a tool, which will spawn items based on how that tool would break the block
(ie: When using a hand to break stone, it drops nothing, whereas with a pickaxe it drops cobblestone)
effects.examples:
on right click:
break clicked block naturally
loop blocks in radius 10 around player:
break loop-block using player's tool
loop blocks in radius 10 around player:
break loop-block naturally using diamond pickaxe

effects.name: Broadcast
effects.description: Broadcasts a message to the server.
effects.examples:
broadcast "Welcome %player% to the server!"
broadcast "Woah! It's a message!"

effects.name: Cancel Active Item
effects.description:
Interrupts the action entities may be trying to complete.
For example, interrupting eating, or drawing back a bow.
effects.examples:
on damage of player:
if the victim's active tool is a bow:
interrupt the usage of the player's active item

effects.name: Cancel Command Cooldown
effects.description: Only usable in commands. Makes it so the current command usage isn't counted towards the cooldown.
effects.examples:
command /nick &lt;text&gt;:
executable by: players
cooldown: 10 seconds
trigger:
if length of arg-1 is more than 16:
# Makes it so that invalid arguments don't make you wait for the cooldown again
cancel the cooldown
send "Your nickname may be at most 16 characters."
stop
set the player's display name to arg-1

effects.name: Cancel Drops
effects.description: Cancels drops of items or experiences in a death or block break event. Please note that this doesn't keep items or experiences of a dead player. If you want to do that, use the Keep Inventory / Experience effect.
effects.examples:
on death of a zombie:
if name of the entity is "&cSpecial":
cancel drops of items

on break of a coal ore:
cancel the experience drops

effects.name: Cancel Event
effects.description: Cancels the event (e.g. prevent blocks from being placed, or damage being taken).
effects.examples:
on damage:
victim is a player
victim has the permission "skript.god"
cancel the event

effects.name: Change: Set/Add/Remove/Delete/Reset
effects.description: A very general effect that can change many expressions. Many expressions can only be set and/or deleted, while some can have things added to or removed from them.
effects.examples:
# set:
Set the player's display name to "&lt;red&gt;%name of player%"
set the block above the victim to lava
# add:
add 2 to the player's health # preferably use '<a href='#EffHealth'>heal</a>' for this
add argument to {blacklist::*}
give a diamond pickaxe of efficiency 5 to the player
increase the data value of the clicked block by 1
# remove:
remove 2 pickaxes from the victim
subtract 2.5 from {points::%uuid of player%}
# remove all:
remove every iron tool from the player
remove all minecarts from {entitylist::*}
# delete:
delete the block below the player
clear drops
delete {variable}
# reset:
reset walk speed of player
reset chunk at the targeted block

effects.name: Charge Entity
effects.description: Charges or uncharges a creeper or wither skull. A creeper is charged when it has been struck by lightning.
effects.examples:
on spawn of creeper:
charge the event-entity

effects.name: Color Items
effects.description: Colors items in a given color. You can also use RGB codes if you feel limited with the 16 default colors. RGB codes are three numbers from 0 to 255 in the order (red, green, blue), where (0,0,0) is black and (255,255,255) is white. Armor is colorable for all Minecraft versions. With Minecraft 1.11 or newer you can also color potions and maps. Note that the colors might not look exactly how you'd expect.
effects.examples:
dye player's helmet blue
color the player's tool red

effects.name: Command
effects.description:
Executes a command. This can be useful to use other plugins in triggers.
If the command is a bungeecord side command, you can use the [bungeecord] option to execute command on the proxy.
effects.examples:
make player execute command "/home"
execute console command "/say Hello everyone!"
execute player bungeecord command "/alert &6Testing Announcement!"

effects.name: Conditional / Unconditional
effects.description: Sets whether the provided command blocks are conditional or not.
effects.examples:
make command block {_block} conditional
make command block {_block} unconditional if {_block} is conditional

effects.name: Connect
patterns: transfer %players% to server %text% [on port %number%]
effects.description:
Connect a player to a server running on your proxy, or any server supporting transfers. Read below for more information.
If the server is running Minecraft 1.20.5 or above, you may specify an IP and Port to transfer a player over to that server.
When transferring players using an IP, the transfer will not complete if the `accepts-transfers` option isn't enabled in `server.properties` for the server specified.
If the port is not provided, it will default to `25565`.
effects.examples:
connect all players to proxy server "hub"
transfer player to server "my.server.com"
transfer player to server "localhost" on port 25566

effects.name: Consume Boosting Firework
effects.description: Prevent the firework used in an 'elytra boost' event to be consumed.
effects.examples:
on elytra boost:
if the used firework will be consumed:
prevent the used firework from being consume

effects.name: Continue
effects.description: Moves the loop to the next iteration. You may also continue an outer loop from an inner one. The loops are labelled from 1 until the current loop, starting with the outermost one.
effects.examples:
# Broadcast online moderators
loop all players:
if loop-value does not have permission "moderator":
continue # filter out non moderators
broadcast "%loop-player% is a moderator!" # Only moderators get broadcast

# Game starting counter
set {_counter} to 11
while {_counter} > 0:
remove 1 from {_counter}
wait a second
if {_counter} != 1, 2, 3, 5 or 10:
continue # only print when counter is 1, 2, 3, 5 or 10
broadcast "Game starting in %{_counter}% second(s)"

effects.name: Copy Into Variable
effects.description:
Copies objects into a variable. When copying a list over to another list, the source list and its sublists are also copied over.
Note: Copying a value into a variable/list will overwrite the existing data.
effects.examples:
set {_foo::bar} to 1
set {_foo::sublist::foobar} to "hey"
copy {_foo::*} to {_copy::*}
broadcast indices of {_copy::*} # bar, sublist
broadcast {_copy::bar} # 1
broadcast {_copy::sublist::foobar} # "hey!"

effects.name: Damage/Heal/Repair
patterns: damage %living entities/item types/slots% by %number% [heart[s]] [with [fake] [damage] cause %damage cause%]
effects.description:
Damage, heal, or repair an entity or item.
Servers running Spigot 1.20.4+ can optionally choose to specify a fake damage cause.
effects.examples:
damage player by 5 hearts
damage player by 3 hearts with fake cause fall
heal the player
repair tool of player

effects.name: Delay
effects.description: Delays the script's execution by a given timespan. Please note that delays are not persistent, e.g. trying to create a tempban script with ban player → wait 7 days → unban player will not work if you restart your server anytime within these 7 days. You also have to be careful even when using small delays!
effects.examples:
wait 2 minutes
halt for 5 minecraft hours
wait a tick

effects.name: Detonate Entities
effects.description: Immediately detonates an entity. Accepted entities are fireworks, TNT minecarts, primed TNT, wind charges and creepers.
effects.examples: detonate last launched firework

effects.name: Do If
effects.description: Execute an effect if a condition is true.
effects.examples:
on join:
give a diamond to the player if the player has permission "rank.vip"

effects.name: Drop
effects.description: Drops one or more items.
effects.examples:
on death of creeper:
drop 1 TNT

effects.name: Enable/Disable/Unload/Reload Script
effects.description:
Enables, disables, unloads, or reloads a script.

Disabling a script unloads it and prepends - to its name so it will not be loaded the next time the server restarts.
If the script reflection experiment is enabled: unloading a script terminates it and removes it from memory, but does not alter the file.
effects.examples:
reload script "test"
enable script file "testing"
unload script file "script.sk"
set {_script} to the script "MyScript.sk"
reload {_script}

effects.name: Enchant/Disenchant
effects.description: Enchant or disenchant an existing item.
effects.examples:
enchant the player's tool with sharpness 5
disenchant the player's tool

effects.name: Enforce Whitelist
effects.description:
Enforces or un-enforce a server's whitelist.
All non-whitelisted players will be kicked upon enforcing the whitelist.
effects.examples:
enforce the whitelist
unenforce the whitelist

effects.name: Entity Visibility
effects.description:
Change visibility of the given entities for the given players.
If no players are given, will hide the entities from all online players.

When reveal is used in combination of the hidden players expression and the viewers are not specified, this will default it to the given player in the hidden players expression.

Note: all previously hidden entities (including players) will be visible when a player leaves and rejoins.
effects.examples:
