Display Name: The custom name of the entity. Can be changed, which will also enable custom name visibility of the entity so name tag of the entity will be visible always.

Items:
Name and Display Name: The custom name of the item (not the Minecraft locale name). Can be changed.

Inventories:
Name and Display Name: The name/title of the inventory. Changing name of an inventory means opening the same inventory with the same contents but with a different name to its current viewers.

Gamerules:
Name: The name of the gamerule. Cannot be changed.

Worlds:
Name: The name of the world. Cannot be changed.

Scripts:
Name: The name of a script, excluding its file extension.
expressions.examples:
on join:
player has permission "name.red"
set the player's display name to "&lt;red&gt;[admin] &lt;gold&gt;%name of player%"
set the player's tab list name to "&lt;green&gt;%player's name%"
set the name of the player's tool to "Legendary Sword of Awesomeness"

expressions.name: Named Item/Inventory
expressions.description: Directly names an item/inventory, useful for defining a named item/inventory in a script. If you want to (re)name existing items/inventories you can either use this expression or use set name of <item/inventory> to <text>.
expressions.examples:
give a diamond sword of sharpness 100 named "&lt;gold&gt;Excalibur" to the player
set tool of player to the player's tool named "&lt;gold&gt;Wand"
set the name of the player's tool to "&lt;gold&gt;Wand"
open hopper inventory named "Magic Hopper" to player

expressions.name: Nearest Entity
expressions.description: Gets the entity nearest to a location or another entity.
expressions.examples:
kill the nearest pig and cow relative to player
teleport player to the nearest cow relative to player
teleport player to the nearest entity relative to player

on click:
kill nearest pig

expressions.name: New Line
expressions.description: Returns a line break separator.
expressions.examples: send "Hello%nl%Goodbye!" to player

expressions.name: No Damage Ticks
expressions.description: The number of ticks that an entity is invulnerable to damage for.
expressions.examples:
on damage:
set victim's invulnerability ticks to 20 #Victim will not take damage for the next second

expressions.name: Node (Experimental)
expressions.description:
Returns a node inside a config (or another section-node).
Nodes in Skript configs are written in the format `key: value`.
Section nodes can contain other nodes.
expressions.examples:
set {_node} to node "language" in the skript config if text value of {_node} is "french": broadcast "Bonjour!"
set {_script} to the current script loop nodes of the current script: broadcast name of loop-value

expressions.name: Now
expressions.description: The current system time of the server. Use time to get the Minecraft time of a world.
expressions.examples: broadcast "Current server time: %now%"

expressions.name: Number of Characters
patterns: number of upper[ ]case char(acters|s) in %text%
number of lower[ ]case char(acters|s) in %text%
number of digit char(acters|s) in %text%
expressions.description: The number of uppercase, lowercase, or digit characters in a string.
expressions.examples:
#Simple Chat Filter
on chat:
if number of uppercase chars in message / length of message > 0.5
cancel event
send "&lt;red&gt;Your message has to many caps!" to player

expressions.name: Numbers
expressions.description:
All numbers between two given numbers, useful for looping.
Use 'numbers' if your start is not an integer and you want to keep the fractional part of the start number constant, or use 'integers' if you only want to loop integers.
You may also use 'decimals' if you want to use the decimal precision of the start number.
You may want to use the 'times' expression instead, for instance 'loop 5 times:'
expressions.examples:
loop numbers from 2.5 to 5.5: # loops 2.5, 3.5, 4.5, 5.5
loop integers from 2.9 to 5.1: # same as '3 to 5', i.e. loops 3, 4, 5
loop decimals from 3.94 to 4: # loops 3.94, 3.95, 3.96, 3.97, 3.98, 3.99, 4

expressions.name: Offline players
expressions.description: All players that have ever joined the server. This includes the players currently online.
expressions.examples: send "Size of all players who have joined the server: %size of all offline players%"

expressions.name: Online Player Count
expressions.description:
The amount of online players. This can be changed in a server list ping event only to show fake online player amount.
real online player count always return the real count of online players and can't be changed.
expressions.examples:
on server list ping:
# This will make the max players count 5 if there are 4 players online.
set the fake max players count to (online player count + 1)

expressions.name: Opened Inventory
expressions.description:
Return the currently opened inventory of a player.
If no inventory is open, it returns the own player's crafting inventory.
expressions.examples: set slot 1 of player's current inventory to diamond sword

expressions.name: Parse
expressions.description:
Parses text as a given type, or as a given pattern.
This expression can be used in two different ways: One which parses the entire text as a single instance of a type, e.g. as a number, and one that parses the text according to a pattern.
If the given text could not be parsed, this expression will return nothing and the parse error will be set if some information is available.
Some notes about parsing with a pattern:
- The pattern must be a Skript pattern, e.g. percent signs are used to define where to parse which types, e.g. put a %number% or %items% in the pattern if you expect a number or some items there.
- You have to save the expression's value in a list variable, e.g. set {parsed::*} to message parsed as "...".
- The list variable will contain the parsed values from all %types% in the pattern in order. If a type was plural, e.g. %items%, the variable's value at the respective index will be a list variable, e.g. the values will be stored in {parsed::1::*}, not {parsed::1}.
expressions.examples:
set {var} to line 1 parsed as number
on chat:
set {var::*} to message parsed as "buying %items% for %money%"
if parse error is set:
message "%parse error%"
else if {var::*} is set:
cancel event
remove {var::2} from the player's balance
give {var::1::*} to the player

expressions.name: Parse Error
expressions.description: The error which caused the last parse operation to fail, which might not be set if a pattern was used and the pattern didn't match the provided text at all.
expressions.examples:
set {var} to line 1 parsed as integer
if {var} is not set:
parse error is set:
message "&lt;red&gt;Line 1 is invalid: %last parse error%"
else:
message "&lt;red&gt;Please put an integer on line 1!"

expressions.name: Passenger
expressions.description:
The passenger of a vehicle, or the rider of a mob.
For 1.11.2 and above, it returns a list of passengers and you can use all changers in it.
See also: vehicle
expressions.examples:
#for 1.11 and lower
passenger of the minecart is a creeper or a cow
the saddled pig's passenger is a player
#for 1.11.2+
passengers of the minecart contains a creeper or a cow
the boat's passenger contains a pig
add a cow and a zombie to passengers of last spawned boat
set passengers of player's vehicle to a pig and a horse
remove all pigs from player's vehicle
clear passengers of boat

expressions.name: Percent of
expressions.description: Returns a percentage of one or more numbers.
expressions.examples:
set damage to 10% of victim's health
set damage to 125 percent of damage
set {_result} to {_percent} percent of 999
set {_result::*} to 10% of {_numbers::*}
set experience to 50% of player's total experience

expressions.name: Pi
expressions.description: Returns the mathematical constant pi. (approx. 3.1415926535)
expressions.examples: set {_tau} to pi * 2

expressions.name: Pickup Delay
expressions.description: The amount of time before a dropped item can be picked up by an entity.
expressions.examples:
drop diamond sword at {_location} without velocity
set pickup delay of last dropped item to 5 seconds

expressions.name: Ping
expressions.description: Pings of players, as Minecraft server knows them. Note that they will almost certainly be different from the ones you'd get from using ICMP echo requests. This expression is only supported on some server software (PaperSpigot).
expressions.examples:
command /ping <player=%player%>:
trigger:
send "%arg-1%'s ping is %arg-1's ping%"

expressions.name: Plain Item
expressions.description: A plain item is an item with no modifications. It can be used to convert items to their default state or to match with other default items.
expressions.examples:
if the player's tool is a plain diamond: # check if player's tool has no modifications
send "You are holding a plain diamond!"

expressions.name: Player Chat Completions
expressions.description:
The custom chat completion suggestions. You can add, set, remove, and clear them. Removing the names of online players with this expression is ineffective.
This expression will not return anything due to Bukkit limitations.
expressions.examples:
add "Skript" and "Njol" to chat completions of all players
remove "text" from {_p}'s chat completions
clear player's chat completions

expressions.name: Player Input Keys
expressions.description: Get the current input keys of a player.
expressions.examples: broadcast "%player% is pressing %current input keys of player%"

expressions.name: Player List Header and Footer
expressions.description: The message above and below the player list in the tab menu.
expressions.examples:
set all players' tab list header to "Welcome to the Server!"
send "%the player's tab list header%" to player
reset all players' tab list header

expressions.name: Player Protocol Version
expressions.description: Player's protocol version. For more information and list of protocol versions visit wiki.vg.
expressions.examples:
command /protocolversion &ltplayer&gt:
trigger:
send "Protocol version of %arg-1%: %protocol version of arg-1%"

expressions.name: Player Skull
expressions.description: Gets a skull item representing a player. Skulls for other entities are provided by the aliases.
expressions.examples:
give the victim's skull to the attacker
set the block at the entity to the entity's skull

expressions.name: Player Weather
expressions.description: The weather for a player.
expressions.examples:
set weather of arg-player to rainy
reset player's weather
if arg-player's weather is rainy

expressions.name: Portal
expressions.description: The blocks associated with a portal in the portal creation event.
expressions.examples:
on portal creation:
loop portal blocks:
broadcast "%loop-block% is part of a portal!"

expressions.name: Portal Cooldown
expressions.description:
The amount of time before an entity can use a portal. By default, it is 15 seconds after exiting a nether portal or end gateway.
Players in survival/adventure get a cooldown of 0.5 seconds, while those in creative get no cooldown.
Resetting will set the cooldown back to the default 15 seconds for non-player entities and 0.5 seconds for players.
expressions.examples:
on portal:
wait 1 tick
set portal cooldown of event-entity to 5 seconds

expressions.name: Potion Effect
patterns: [new] potion effect of %potion effect type% [potion] [[[of] tier] %number%] [without particles] [for %time span%]
[new] ambient potion effect of %potion effect type% [potion] [[[of] tier] %number%] [without particles] [for %time span%]
expressions.description:
Create a new potion effect to apply to an entity or item type. Do note that when applying potion effects
to tipped arrows/lingering potions, Minecraft reduces the timespan.
expressions.examples:
set {_p} to potion effect of speed of tier 1 without particles for 10 minutes
add {_p} to potion effects of player's tool
add {_p} to potion effects of target entity
add potion effect of speed 1 to potion effects of player

expressions.name: Potion Effect Tier
expressions.description: An expression to obtain the amplifier of a potion effect applied to an entity.
expressions.examples: if the amplifier of haste of player &gt;= 3:

expressions.name: Potion Effects
patterns: [the] [(all [[of] the]|the)] [active] potion effects of %living entities/item types%
%living entities/item types%'[s] [(all [[of] the]|the)] [active] potion effects
expressions.description:
Represents the active potion effects of entities and itemtypes.
You can clear all potion effects of an entity/itemtype and add/remove a potion effect/type to/from an entity/itemtype.
Do note you will not be able to clear the base potion effects of a potion item. In that case, just set the item to a water bottle.
When adding a potion effect type (rather than a potion effect), it will default to 15 seconds with tier 1.
expressions.examples:
set {_p::*} to active potion effects of player
clear all the potion effects of player
clear all the potion effects of player's tool
add potion effects of player to potion effects of player's tool
add speed to potion effects of target entity
remove speed and night vision from potion effects of player

expressions.name: Prefix/Suffix
expressions.description: The prefix or suffix as defined in the server's chat plugin.
expressions.examples:
on chat:
cancel event
broadcast "%player's prefix%%player's display name%%player's suffix%: %message%" to the player's world

set the player's prefix to "[&lt;red&gt;Admin<reset>] "

clear player's prefix

expressions.name: Projectile Critical State
expressions.description: A projectile's critical state. The only currently accepted projectiles are arrows and tridents.
expressions.examples:
on shoot:
event-projectile is an arrow
set projectile critical mode of event-projectile to true

expressions.name: Protocol Version
expressions.description:
The protocol version that will be sent as the protocol version of the server in a server list ping event. For more information and list of protocol versions visit wiki.vg.
If this protocol version doesn't match with the protocol version of the client, the client will see the version string.
But please note that, this expression has no visual effect over the version string. For example if the server uses PaperSpigot 1.12.2, and you make the protocol version 107 (1.9),
the version string will not be "Paper 1.9", it will still be "Paper 1.12.2".
But then you can customize the version string as you wish.
Also if the protocol version of the player is higher than protocol version of the server, it will say
"Server out of date!", and if vice-versa "Client out of date!" when you hover on the ping bars.

This can be set in a server list ping event only
(increase and decrease effects cannot be used because that wouldn't make sense).
expressions.examples:
on server list ping:
set the version string to "&lt;light green&gt;Version: &lt;orange&gt;%minecraft version%"
set the protocol version to 0 # 13w41a (1.7) - so the player will see the custom version string almost always

expressions.name: Queue (Experimental)
expressions.description: Requires the using queues experimental feature flag to be enabled. Creates a new queue. A queue is a set of elements that can have things removed from the start and added to the end. Any value can be added to a queue. Adding a non-existent value (e.g. `{variable that isn't set}`) will have no effect. This means that removing an element from the queue will always return a value unless the queue is empty. Requesting an element from a queue (e.g. `the 1st element of {queue}`) also removes it from the queue.
expressions.examples:
set {queue} to a new queue add "hello" and "there" to {queue} broadcast the first element of {queue} # hello broadcast the first element of {queue} # there # queue is now empty
set {queue} to a new queue of "hello" and "there" broadcast the last element of {queue} # removes 'there' add "world" to {queue} broadcast the first 2 elements of {queue} # removes 'hello', 'world'

expressions.name: Queue Start/End (Experimental)
expressions.description: Requires the using queues experimental feature flag to be enabled. The first or last element in a queue. Asking for this does not remove the element from the queue. This is designed for use with the add changer: to add or remove elements from the start or the end of the queue.

expressions.name: Quit Reason
expressions.description: The quit reason as to why a player disconnected in a quit event.
expressions.examples:
on quit:
quit reason was kicked
player is banned
clear {server::player::%uuid of player%::*}

expressions.name: Random
expressions.description: Gets a random item out of a set, e.g. a random player out of all players online.
expressions.examples:
give a diamond to a random player out of all players
give a random item out of all items to the player

expressions.name: Random Character
expressions.description:
One or more random characters between two given characters. Use 'alphanumeric' if you want only alphanumeric characters.
This expression uses the Unicode numerical code of a character to determine which characters are between the two given characters.
If strings of more than one character are given, only the first character of each is used.
expressions.examples:
set {_captcha} to join (5 random characters between "a" and "z") with ""
send 3 random alphanumeric characters between "0" and "z"

expressions.name: Random Numbers
expressions.description:
A given amount of random numbers or integers between two given numbers. Use 'number' if you want any number with decimal parts, or use use 'integer' if you only want whole numbers.
Please note that the order of the numbers doesn't matter, i.e. random number between 2 and 1 will work as well as random number between 1 and 2.
expressions.examples:
set the player's health to a random number between 5 and 10
send "You rolled a %random integer from 1 to 6%!" to the player
set {_chances::*} to 5 random integers between 5 and 96
set {_decimals::*} to 3 random numbers between 2.7 and -1.5

expressions.name: Random UUID
expressions.description: Returns a random UUID.
expressions.examples: set {_uuid} to random uuid

expressions.name: Raw Name
expressions.description: The raw Minecraft material name of the given item. Note that this is not guaranteed to give same results on all servers.
expressions.examples: raw name of tool of player

expressions.name: Raw String
expressions.description: Returns the string without formatting (colors etc.) and without stripping them from it, e.g. raw "&aHello There!" would output &aHello There!
expressions.examples: send raw "&amp;aThis text is unformatted!" to all players

expressions.name: Readied Arrow/Bow
expressions.description: The bow or arrow in a Ready Arrow event.
expressions.examples:
on player ready arrow:
selected bow's name is "Spectral Bow"
if selected arrow is not a spectral arrow:
cancel event

expressions.name: Redstone Block Power
expressions.description: Power of a redstone block
expressions.examples:
if redstone power of targeted block is 15:
send "This block is very powerful!"

expressions.name: Region
expressions.description:
The region involved in an event.
This expression requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
expressions.examples:
on region enter:
region is {forbidden region}
cancel the event

expressions.name: Region Members & Owners
expressions.description:
A list of members or owners of a region.
This expression requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
expressions.examples:
on entering of a region:
message "You're entering %region% whose owners are %owners of region%"

expressions.name: Regions At
expressions.description:
All regions at a particular location.
This expression requires a supported regions plugin to be installed.
expressions.examples:
On click on a sign:
line 1 of the clicked block is "[region info]"
set {_regions::*} to regions at the clicked block
if {_regions::*} is empty:
message "No regions exist at this sign."
else:
message "Regions containing this sign: &lt;gold&gt;%{_regions::*}%<r>."

expressions.name: Remaining Air
expressions.description: How much time a player has left underwater before starting to drown.
expressions.examples:
if the player's remaining air is less than 3 seconds:
send "hurry, get to the surface!" to the player

expressions.name: Repeat String
expressions.description: Repeats inputted strings a given amount of times.
expressions.examples:
broadcast nl and nl repeated 200 times
broadcast "Hello World " repeated 5 times
if "aa" repeated 2 times is "aaaa":
broadcast "Ahhhh" repeated 100 times

expressions.name: Resonating Time
expressions.description:
Returns the resonating time of a bell.
A bell will start resonating five game ticks after being rung, and will continue to resonate for 40 game ticks.
expressions.examples: broadcast "The bell has been resonating for %resonating time of target block%"

expressions.name: Respawn Anchor Charges
expressions.description: The charges of a respawn anchor.
expressions.examples: set the charges of event-block to 3

expressions.name: Respawn location
expressions.description: The location that a player should respawn at. This is used within the respawn event.
expressions.examples:
on respawn:
set respawn location to {example::spawn}

expressions.name: Result (Experimental)
expressions.description:
Runs something (like a function) and returns its result.
If the thing is expected to return multiple values, use 'results' instead of 'result'.
expressions.examples:
set {_function} to the function named "myFunction"
set {_result} to the result of {_function}
set {_list::*} to the results of {_function}
set {_result} to the result of {_function} with arguments 13 and true

expressions.name: Reversed List
expressions.description: Reverses given list.
expressions.examples: set {_list::*} to reversed {_list::*}

expressions.name: Ringing Time
expressions.description:
Returns the ringing time of a bell.
A bell typically rings for 50 game ticks.
expressions.examples: broadcast "The bell has been ringing for %ringing time of target block%"

expressions.name: Rotated Quaternion/Vector
patterns: %quaternions/vectors% rotated around [the] %vector% by %number%
%quaternions% rotated by x %number%, y %number%(, [and]| and) z %number%
expressions.description:
Rotates a quaternion or vector around an axis a set amount of degrees, or around all 3 axes at once.
Vectors can only be rotated around the global X/Y/Z axes, or an arbitrary vector axis.
Quaternions are more flexible, allowing rotation around the global or local X/Y/Z axes, arbitrary vectors, or all 3 local axes at once.
Global axes are the ones in the Minecraft world. Local axes are relative to how the quaternion is already oriented.

Note that rotating a quaternion around a vector results in a rotation around the local vector, so results may not be what you expect. For example, rotating around vector(1, 0, 0) is the same as rotating around the local X axis.
The same applies to rotations by all three axes at once. In addition, rotating around all three axes of a quaternion/display at once will rotate in ZYX order, meaning the Z rotation will be applied first and the X rotation last.
expressions.examples:
set {_new} to {_quaternion} rotated around x axis by 10 degrees
set {_new} to {_vector} rotated around vector(1, 1, 1) by 45
set {_new} to {_quaternion} rotated by x 45, y 90, z 135

expressions.name: Rotation Axis/Angle
expressions.description:
Returns the axis or angle that a quaternion will rotate by/around.
All quaternions can be represented by a rotation of some amount around some axis, so this expression provides the ability to get that angle/axis.
expressions.examples:
set {_quaternion} to axisAngle(45, vector(1, 2, 3))
send rotation axis of {_quaternion} # 1, 2, 3
send rotation angle of {_quaternion} # 45
set rotation angle of {_quaternion} to 135
set rotation axis of {_quaternion} to vector(0, 1, 0)

expressions.name: Rounding
expressions.description: Rounds numbers normally, up (ceiling) or down (floor) respectively.
expressions.examples:
set {var} to rounded health of player
set line 1 of the block to rounded "%(1.5 * player's level)%"
add rounded down argument to the player's health

expressions.name: Saturation
expressions.description: The saturation of a player. If used in a player event, it can be omitted and will default to event-player.
expressions.examples: set saturation of player to 20

expressions.name: Scoreboard Tags
expressions.description:
Scoreboard tags are simple list of texts stored directly in the data of an entity.
So this is a Minecraft related thing, not Bukkit, so the tags will not get removed when the server stops. You can visit visit Minecraft Wiki for more info.
This is changeable and valid for any type of entity. Also you can use use the Has Scoreboard Tag condition to check whether an entity has the given tags.

Requires Minecraft 1.11+ (actually added in 1.9 to the game, but added in 1.11 to Spigot).
expressions.examples:
on spawn of a monster:
if the spawn reason is mob spawner:
add "spawned by a spawner" to the scoreboard tags of event-entity

on death of a monster:
if the attacker is a player:
if the victim doesn't have the scoreboard tag "spawned by a spawner":
add 1$ to attacker's balance

expressions.name: Script
expressions.description:
The current script, or a script from its (file) name.
If the script is enabled or disabled (or reloaded) this reference will become invalid.
Therefore, it is recommended to obtain a script reference when needed.
expressions.examples:
on script load:
broadcast "Loaded %the current script%"
on script load:
set {running::%script%} to true
on script unload:
set {running::%script%} to false
set {script} to the script named "weather.sk"
loop the scripts in directory "quests/":
enable loop-value

expressions.name: Sea Level
expressions.description: Gets the sea level of a world.
expressions.examples: send "The sea level in your world is %sea level in player's world%"

expressions.name: Sea Pickles
expressions.description: An expression to obtain or modify data relating to the pickles of a sea pickle block.
expressions.examples:
on block break:
type of block is sea pickle
send "Wow! This stack of sea pickles contained %event-block's sea pickle count% pickles!"
send "It could've contained a maximum of %event-block's maximum sea pickle count% pickles!"
send "It had to have contained at least %event-block's minimum sea pickle count% pickles!"
cancel event
set event-block's sea pickle count to event-block's maximum sea pickle count
send "This bad boy is going to hold so many pickles now!!"

expressions.name: Seed of Loot Table
expressions.description: Returns the seed of a loot table. Setting the seed of a block or entity that does not have a loot table will not do anything.
expressions.examples:
set {_seed} loot table seed of block
set loot table seed of entity to 123456789

expressions.name: Sent Command List
expressions.description:
The commands that will be sent to the player in a send commands to player event.
Modifications will affect what commands show up for the player to tab complete. They will not affect what commands the player can actually run.
Adding new commands to the list is illegal behavior and will be ignored.
expressions.examples:
on send command list:
set command list to command list where [input does not contain ":"]
remove "help" from command list

expressions.name: Server Icon
expressions.description:
Icon of the server in the server list. Can be set to an icon that loaded using the
load server icon effect,
or can be reset to the default icon in a server list ping.
'default server icon' returns the default server icon (server-icon.png) always and cannot be changed.
expressions.examples:
on script load:
set {server-icons::default} to the default server icon

expressions.name: Sets
expressions.description: Returns a list of all the values of a type. Useful for looping.
expressions.examples:
loop all attribute types:
set loop-value attribute of player to 10
message "Set attribute %loop-value% to 10!"

expressions.name: Shooter
expressions.description: The shooter of a projectile.
expressions.examples: shooter is a skeleton

expressions.name: Shuffled List
expressions.description: Shuffles given list randomly. This is done by replacing indices by random numbers in resulting list.
expressions.examples: set {_list::*} to shuffled {_list::*}

expressions.name: Sign Text
expressions.description: A line of text on a sign. Can be changed, but remember that there is a 16 character limit per line (including color codes that use 2 characters each).
expressions.examples:
on rightclick on sign:
line 2 of the clicked block is "[Heal]":
heal the player
set line 3 to "%player%"

expressions.name: Skull Owner
patterns: [the] (head|skull) owner of %slots/item types/item stacks/blocks%
%slots/item types/item stacks/blocks%'[s] (head|skull) owner
expressions.description: The skull owner of a player skull.
expressions.examples:
set {_owner} to the skull owner of event-block
set skull owner of {_block} to "Njol" parsed as offlineplayer
set head owner of player's tool to {_player}

expressions.name: Slot Index
expressions.description:
Index of an an inventory slot. Other types of slots may or may not have indices. Note that comparing slots with numbers is also possible; if index of slot is same as the number, comparisonsucceeds. This expression is mainly for the cases where you must for some reason save the slot numbers.

Raw index of slot is unique for the view, see Minecraft Wiki
expressions.examples:
if index of event-slot is 10:
send "You bought a pie!"

if display name of player's top inventory is "Custom Menu": # 3 rows inventory
if raw index of event-slot > 27: # outside custom inventory
cancel event

expressions.name: Sorted List
expressions.description: Sorts given list in natural order. All objects in list must be comparable; if they're not, this expression will return nothing.
expressions.examples: set {_sorted::*} to sorted {_players::*}

expressions.name: Source Block
expressions.description: The source block in a spread event.
expressions.examples:
on spread:
if the source block is a grass block:
set the source block to dirt

expressions.name: Spawn
expressions.description: The spawn point of a world.
expressions.examples:
teleport all players to spawn
set the spawn point of "world" to the player's location

expressions.name: Spawn Egg Entity
patterns: [the] spawn egg entity of %item stacks/item types/slots%
%item stacks/item types/slots%'[s] spawn egg entity
expressions.description: Gets or sets the entity snapshot that the provided spawn eggs will spawn when used.
expressions.examples:
set {_item} to a zombie spawn egg
broadcast the spawn egg entity of {_item}

spawn a pig at location(0,0,0):
set the max health of entity to 20
set the health of entity to 20
set {_snapshot} to the entity snapshot of entity
clear entity
set the spawn egg entity of {_item} to {_snapshot}
if the spawn egg entity of {_item} is {_snapshot}: # Minecraft 1.20.5+

set the spawn egg entity of {_item} to (random element out of all entities)

set the spawn egg entity of {_item} to a zombie

expressions.name: Spawn Reason
expressions.description: The spawn reason in a spawn event.
expressions.examples:
on spawn:
spawn reason is reinforcements or breeding
cancel event

expressions.name: Spawner Type
expressions.description: Retrieves, sets, or resets the spawner's entity type
expressions.examples:
on right click:
if event-block is spawner:
send "Spawner's type is %target block's entity type%"

expressions.name: Special Number
expressions.description: Special number values, namely NaN, Infinity and -Infinity
expressions.examples: if {_number} is infinity value:

expressions.name: Spectator Target
expressions.description: Grabs the spectator target entity of the players.
expressions.examples:
on player start spectating of player:
message "&c%spectator target% currently has %{game::kills::%spectator target%}% kills!" to the player

on player stop spectating:
past spectator target was a zombie
set spectator target to the nearest skeleton

expressions.name: Speed
expressions.description:
A player's walking or flying speed. Both can be changed, but values must be between -1 and 1 (excessive values will be changed to -1 or 1 respectively). Negative values reverse directions.
Please note that changing a player's speed will change their FOV just like potions do.
expressions.examples:
set the player's walk speed to 1
increase the argument's fly speed by 0.1

expressions.name: Substring
expressions.description: Extracts part of a text. You can either get the first <x> characters, the last <x> characters, the character at index <x>, or the characters between indices <x> and <y>. The indices <x> and <y> should be between 1 and the length of the text (other values will be fit into this range).
expressions.examples:
set {_s} to the first 5 characters of the text argument
message "%subtext of {_s} from characters 2 to (the length of {_s} - 1)%" # removes the first and last character from {_s} and sends it to the player or console
set {_characters::*} to characters at 1, 2 and 7 in player's display name
send the last character of all players' names

expressions.name: TPS (ticks per second)
expressions.description: Returns the 3 most recent TPS readings, like the /tps command. This expression is only supported on some server software (PaperSpigot).
expressions.examples: broadcast "%tps%"

expressions.name: Tag
expressions.description:
Represents a tag which can be used to classify items, blocks, or entities.
Tags are composed of a value and an optional namespace: "minecraft:oak_logs".
If you omit the namespace, one will be provided for you, depending on what kind of tag you're using. For example, `tag "doors"` will be the tag "minecraft:doors", while `paper tag "doors"` will be "paper:doors".
`minecraft tag` will search through the vanilla tags, `datapack tag` will search for datapack-provided tags (a namespace is required here!), `paper tag` will search for Paper's custom tags if you are running Paper, and `custom tag` will look in the "skript" namespace for custom tags you've registered.
You can also filter by tag types using "item", "block", or "entity".
expressions.examples:
minecraft tag "dirt" # minecraft:dirt
paper tag "doors" # paper:doors
tag "skript:custom_dirt" # skript:custom_dirt
custom tag "dirt" # skript:dirt
datapack block tag "dirt" # minecraft:dirt
datapack tag "my_pack:custom_dirt" # my_pack:custom_dirt
tag "minecraft:mineable/pickaxe" # minecraft:mineable/pickaxe
custom item tag "blood_magic_sk/can_sacrifice_with" # skript:blood_magic_sk/can_sacrifice_with

expressions.name: Tag Namespaced Key
expressions.description: The namespaced key of a minecraft tag. This takes the form of "namespace:key", e.g. "minecraft:dirt".
expressions.examples:
broadcast namespaced keys of the tags of player's tool
if the key of {_my-tag} is "minecraft:stone":
return true

expressions.name: Tags Contents
expressions.description:
Returns all the values that a tag contains.
For item and block tags, this will return items. For entity tags, it will return entity datas (a creeper, a zombie).
expressions.examples:
broadcast tag values of minecraft tag "dirt"
broadcast (first element of player's tool's block tags)'s tag contents

expressions.name: Tags of X
patterns: [all [[of] the]|the] [minecraft|datapack|paper|custom] [item|block|entity [type]] tags of %item type/entity/entity type%
expressions.description:
Returns all the tags of an item, block, or entity.
`minecraft tag` will return only the vanilla tags, `datapack tag` will return only datapack-provided tags, `paper tag` will return only Paper's custom tags (if you are running Paper), and `custom tag` will look in the "skript" namespace for custom tags you've registered.
You can also filter by tag types using "item", "block", or "entity".
expressions.examples:
broadcast minecraft tags of dirt
send true if paper item tags of target block contains paper tag "doors"
broadcast the block tags of player's tool

expressions.name: Tamer
expressions.description: The tamer of an entity. Can only be used in entity tame events. You can use 'event-entity' to refer tamed entity itself.
expressions.examples:
on tame:
if the tamer is a player:
send "someone tamed something!" to console

expressions.name: Target
patterns: [the] target[[ed] %*entity type%] [of %living entities%] [ignoring blocks] [[with|at] ray[ ]size %number%]
%living entities%'[s] target[[ed] %*entity type%] [ignoring blocks] [[with|at] ray[ ]size %number%]
expressions.description:
For players this is the entity at the crosshair.
For mobs and experience orbs this is the entity they are attacking/following (if any).
Display entities have a hit box of 0, so you should use 'target display' to collect Display entities
May grab entities in unloaded chunks.
expressions.examples:
on entity target:
if entity's target is a player:
send "You're being followed by an %entity%!" to target of entity

reset target of entity # Makes the entity target-less
delete targeted entity of player # for players it will delete the target
delete target of last spawned zombie # for entities it will make them target-less

expressions.name: Targeted Block
expressions.description:
The block at the crosshair. This regards all blocks that are not air as fully solid, e.g. torches will be like a solid stone block for this expression.
The actual target block will regard the actual hit box of the block.
expressions.examples:
set target block of player to stone
set target block of player to oak_stairs[waterlogged=true]
break target block of player using player's tool
give player 1 of type of target block
teleport player to location above target block
kill all entities in radius 3 around target block of player
set {_block} to actual target block of player
break actual target block of player

expressions.name: Teleport Cause
expressions.description: The teleport cause within a player teleport event.
expressions.examples:
on teleport:
teleport cause is nether portal, end portal or end gateway
cancel event

expressions.name: Temperature
expressions.description: Temperature at given block.
expressions.examples: message "%temperature of the targeted block%"

expressions.name: Ternary
expressions.description: A shorthand expression for returning something based on a condition.
expressions.examples: set {points} to 500 if {admin::%player's uuid%} is set else 100

expressions.name: Text Display Alignment
expressions.description: Returns or changes the alignment setting of text displays.
expressions.examples: set text alignment of the last spawned text display to left aligned

expressions.name: Text Display Line Width
expressions.description: Returns or changes the line width of text displays. Default is 200.
expressions.examples: set the line width of the last spawned text display to 300

expressions.name: Text Display Opacity
expressions.description:
Returns or changes the opacity of text displays.
Values are between -127 and 127. The value of 127 represents it being completely opaque.
expressions.examples: set the opacity of the last spawned text display to -1 # Reset

expressions.name: Text Of
expressions.description:
Returns or changes the text/string of displays.
Note that currently you can only use Skript chat codes when running Paper.
expressions.examples: set text of the last spawned text display to "example"

expressions.name: The Egg
expressions.description: The egg thrown in a Player Egg Throw event.
expressions.examples: spawn an egg at the egg

expressions.name: Time
expressions.description:
The time of a world.
Use the "minecraft timespan" syntax to change the time according to Minecraft's time intervals.
Since Minecraft uses discrete intervals for time (ticks), changing the time by real-world minutes or real-world seconds only changes it approximately.
Removing an amount of time from a world's time will move the clock forward a day.
expressions.examples:
set time of world "world" to 2:00
add 2 minecraft hours to time of world "world"
add 54 real seconds to time of world "world" # approximately 1 minecraft hour

expressions.name: Time Played
expressions.description:
The amount of time a player has played for on the server. This info is stored in the player's statistics in the main world's data folder. Changing this will also change the player's stats which can be views in the client's statistics menu.
Using this expression on offline players on Minecraft 1.14 and below will return nothing <none>.
expressions.examples:
set {_t} to time played of player
if player's time played is greater than 10 minutes:
give player a diamond sword

set player's time played to 0 seconds

expressions.name: Time Since/Until
expressions.description:
The time since a date has passed or the time until a date will pass.
This expression will return 0 seconds if the time since or time until would be negative, e.g. if one tries to get the time since a future date.
expressions.examples:
send "%time since 5 minecraft days ago% has passed since 5 minecraft days ago!" to player
send "%time until {countdown::end}% until the game begins!" to player

expressions.name: Timespan Details
expressions.description: Retrieve specific information of a timespan such as hours/minutes/etc.
expressions.examples:
set {_t} to difference between now and {Payouts::players::%uuid of player%::last-date}
send "It has been %days of {_t}% day(s) since last payout."

expressions.name: Tool
expressions.description: The item an entity is holding in their main or off hand.
expressions.examples:
player's tool is a pickaxe
player's off hand tool is a shield
set tool of all players to a diamond sword
set offhand tool of target entity to a bow

expressions.name: Total Experience
expressions.description:
The total experience, in points, of players or experience orbs.
Adding to a player's experience will trigger Mending, but setting their experience will not.
expressions.examples:
set total experience of player to 100

add 100 to player's experience

if player's total experience is greater than 100:
set player's total experience to 0
give player 1 diamond

expressions.name: Transform Reason
expressions.description: The transform reason within an entity entity transform event.
expressions.examples:
on entity transform:
transform reason is infection, drowned or frozen

expressions.name: Transformed List
expressions.description:
Transforms (or 'maps') a list's values using a given expression. This is akin to looping over the list and getting a modified version of each value.
Indices cannot be retained with this expression. To retain indices, see the transform effect.
expressions.examples:
set {_a::*} to (1, 2, and 3) transformed using (input * 2 - 1, input * 2)
# {_a::*} is now 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6

# get a list of the sizes of all clans without manually looping
set {_clan-sizes::*} to indices of {clans::*} transformed using [{clans::%input%::size}]

expressions.name: Type of
patterns: [the] type of %entity types/item types/inventories/potion effects/block datas/enchantment types%
%entity types/item types/inventories/potion effects/block datas/enchantment types%'[s] type
expressions.description:
Type of a block, item, entity, inventory, potion effect or enchantment type.
Types of items, blocks and block datas are item types similar to them but have amounts
of one, no display names and, on Minecraft 1.13 and newer versions, are undamaged.
Types of entities and inventories are entity types and inventory types known to Skript.
Types of potion effects are potion effect types.
Types of enchantment types are enchantments.
expressions.examples:
on rightclick on an entity:
message "This is a %type of clicked entity%!"

expressions.name: UUID
expressions.description: The UUID of a player, entity or world.
expressions.examples:
# prevents people from joining the server if they use the name of a player
# who has played on this server at least once since this script has been added
on login:
if {uuid::%name of player%} exists:
{uuid::%name of player%} is not uuid of player
kick player due to "Someone with your name has played on this server before"
else:
set {uuid::%name of player%} to uuid of player

command /what-is-my-uuid:
trigger:
set {_uuid} to uuid of player
send "Your UUID is '%string within {_uuid}%'"

expressions.name: Unbreakable Items
expressions.description: Creates breakable or unbreakable copies of given items.
expressions.examples:
set {_item} to unbreakable iron sword
give breakable {_weapon} to all players

expressions.name: Unix Date
expressions.description: Converts given Unix timestamp to a date. The Unix timespan represents the number of seconds elapsed since 1 January 1970.
expressions.examples: unix date of 946684800 #1 January 2000 12:00 AM (UTC Time)

expressions.name: Unix Timestamp
expressions.description: Converts given date to Unix timestamp. This is roughly how many seconds have elapsed since 1 January 1970.
expressions.examples: unix timestamp of now

expressions.name: Unleash Reason
expressions.description: The unleash reason in an unleash event.
expressions.examples:
if the unleash reason is distance:
broadcast "The leash was snapped in half."

expressions.name: Value
expressions.description:
Returns the value of something that has a value, e.g. a node in a config.
The value is automatically converted to the specified type (e.g. text, number) where possible.
expressions.examples:
set {_node} to node "language" in the skript config broadcast the text value of {_node}
set {_node} to node "update check interval" in the skript config broadcast text value of {_node} # text value of {_node} = "12 hours" (text) wait for {_node}'s timespan value # timespan value of {_node} = 12 hours (duration)

expressions.name: Value Within
expressions.description: Gets the value within objects. Usually used with variables to get the value they store rather than the variable itself, or with lists to get the values of a type.
expressions.examples:
set {_entity} to a random entity out of all entities
delete entity within {_entity} # This deletes the entity itself and not the value stored in the variable

set {_list::*} to "something", 10, "test" and a zombie
broadcast the strings within {_list::*} # "something", "test"

expressions.name: Vector/Quaternion - WXYZ Component
expressions.description:
Gets or changes the W, X, Y or Z component of vectors/quaternions.
You cannot use the W component with vectors; it is for quaternions only.
expressions.examples:
set {_v} to vector 1, 2, 3
send "%x of {_v}%, %y of {_v}%, %z of {_v}%"
add 1 to x of {_v}
add 2 to y of {_v}
add 3 to z of {_v}
send "%x of {_v}%, %y of {_v}%, %z of {_v}%"
set x component of {_v} to 1
set y component of {_v} to 2
set z component of {_v} to 3
send "%x component of {_v}%, %y component of {_v}%, %z component of {_v}%"

expressions.name: Vectors - Angle Between
patterns: [the] angle between [[the] vectors] %vector% and %vector%
expressions.description: Gets the angle between two vectors.
expressions.examples: send "%the angle between vector 1, 0, 0 and vector 0, 1, 1%"

expressions.name: Vectors - Create Location from Vector
patterns: %vector% [to location] in %world% with yaw %number% and pitch %number%
location (from|of) %vector% in %world% with yaw %number% and pitch %number%
expressions.description: Creates a location from a vector in a world.
expressions.examples:
set {_loc} to {_v} to location in world "world"
set {_loc} to {_v} to location in world "world" with yaw 45 and pitch 90
set {_loc} to location of {_v} in "world" with yaw 45 and pitch 90

expressions.name: Vectors - Create from Direction
expressions.description:
Creates vectors from given directions.
Relative directions are relative to the origin, (0, 0, 0). Therefore, the vector from the direction 'forwards' is (0, 0, 1).
expressions.examples:
set {_v} to vector from direction upwards
set {_v} to vector in direction of player
set {_v} to vector in horizontal direction of player
set {_v} to vector from facing of player
set {_v::*} to vectors from north, south, east, and west

expressions.name: Vectors - Create from XYZ
expressions.description: Creates a vector from x, y and z values.
expressions.examples: set {_v} to vector 0, 1, 0

expressions.name: Vectors - Cross Product
expressions.description: Gets the cross product between two vectors.
expressions.examples: send "%vector 1, 0, 0 cross vector 0, 1, 0%"

expressions.name: Vectors - Cylindrical Shape
patterns: [a] [new] cylindrical vector [from|with] [radius] %number%, [yaw] %number%(,[ and]| and) [height] %number%
expressions.description: Forms a 'cylindrical shaped' vector using yaw to manipulate the current point.
expressions.examples:
loop 360 times:
set {_v} to cylindrical vector radius 1, yaw loop-value, height 2
set {_v} to cylindrical vector radius 1, yaw 90, height 2

expressions.name: Vectors - Dot Product
expressions.description: Gets the dot product between two vectors.
expressions.examples: set {_dot} to {_v1} dot {_v2}

expressions.name: Vectors - Length
expressions.description: Gets or sets the length of a vector.
expressions.examples:
send "%standard length of vector 1, 2, 3%"
set {_v} to vector 1, 2, 3
set standard length of {_v} to 2
send "%standard length of {_v}%"

expressions.name: Vectors - Location Vector Offset
expressions.description: Returns the location offset by vectors.
expressions.examples: set {_loc} to {_loc} ~ {_v}

expressions.name: Vectors - Normalized
expressions.description: Returns the same vector but with length 1.
expressions.examples: set {_v} to normalized {_v}

expressions.name: Vectors - Random Vector
expressions.description: Creates a random unit vector.
expressions.examples: set {_v} to a random vector

expressions.name: Vectors - Spherical Shape
patterns: [a] [new] spherical vector [(from|with)] [radius] %number%, [yaw] %number%(,[ and]| and) [pitch] %number%
expressions.description: Forms a 'spherical shaped' vector using yaw and pitch to manipulate the current point.
expressions.examples:
loop 360 times:
set {_v} to spherical vector radius 1, yaw loop-value, pitch loop-value
set {_v} to spherical vector radius 1, yaw 45, pitch 90

expressions.name: Vectors - Squared Length
expressions.description: Gets the squared length of a vector.
expressions.examples: send "%squared length of vector 1, 2, 3%"

expressions.name: Vectors - Vector Between Locations
expressions.description: Creates a vector between two locations.
expressions.examples: set {_v} to vector between {_loc1} and {_loc2}

expressions.name: Vectors - Vector Projection
expressions.description: An expression to get the vector projection of two vectors.
expressions.examples: set {_projection} to vector projection of vector(1, 2, 3) onto vector(4, 4, 4)

expressions.name: Vectors - Vector from Location
expressions.description: Creates a vector from a location.
expressions.examples: set {_v} to vector of {_loc}

expressions.name: Vectors - Vector from Yaw and Pitch
patterns: [a] [new] vector (from|with) yaw %number% and pitch %number%
[a] [new] vector (from|with) pitch %number% and yaw %number%
expressions.description: Creates a vector from a yaw and pitch value.
expressions.examples: set {_v} to vector from yaw 45 and pitch 45

expressions.name: Vectors - Velocity
expressions.description: Gets or changes velocity of an entity.
expressions.examples: set player's velocity to {_v}

expressions.name: Vehicle
expressions.description:
The vehicle an entity is in, if any. This can actually be any entity, e.g. spider jockeys are skeletons that ride on a spider, so the spider is the 'vehicle' of the skeleton.
See also: passenger
expressions.examples: vehicle of the player is a minecart

expressions.name: Version
expressions.description: The version of Bukkit, Minecraft or Skript respectively.
expressions.examples:
message "This server is running Minecraft %minecraft version% on Bukkit %bukkit version%"
message "This server is powered by Skript %skript version%"

expressions.name: Version String
expressions.description:
The text to show if the protocol version of the server doesn't match with protocol version of the client. You can check the protocol version expression for more information about this.
This can only be set in a server list ping event.
expressions.examples:
on server list ping:
set the protocol version to 0 # 13w41a (1.7), so it will show the version string always
set the version string to "&lt;light green&gt;Version: &lt;orange&gt;%minecraft version%"

expressions.name: View Distance
expressions.description:
The view distance of a player as set by the server. Can be changed.
NOTE: This is the view distance sent by the server to the player.
This has nothing to do with client side view distance settings
NOTE: This may not work on some versions (such as MC 1.14.x).
The return value in this case will be the view distance set in system.properties.
expressions.examples:
set view distance of player to 10
set {_view} to view distance of player
reset view distance of all players
add 2 to view distance of player

expressions.name: View Distance of Client
expressions.description: The view distance of the client. Can not be changed. This differs from the server side view distance of player as this will retrieve the view distance the player has set on their client.
expressions.examples:
set {_clientView} to the client view distance of player
set view distance of player to client view distance of player

expressions.name: Villager Level/Experience
expressions.description:
Represents the level/experience of a villager.
The level will determine which trades are available to players (value between 1 and 5, defaults to 1).
When a villager's level is 1, they may lose their profession if they don't have a workstation.
Experience works along with the leveling system, determining which level the villager will move to.
Experience must be greater than or equal to 0.
Learn more about villager levels on Minecraft Wiki
expressions.examples:
set {_level} to villager level of {_villager}
set villager level of last spawned villager to 2
add 1 to villager level of target entity
remove 1 from villager level of event-entity
reset villager level of event-entity
set villager experience of last spawned entity to 100

expressions.name: Villager Profession
expressions.description: Represents the profession of a villager/zombie villager.
expressions.examples:
set {_p} to villager profession of event-entity
villager profession of event-entity = nitwit profession
set villager profession of {_villager} to librarian profession
delete villager profession of event-entity

expressions.name: Villager Type
expressions.description: Represents the type of a villager/zombie villager. This usually represents the biome the villager is from.
expressions.examples:
set {_type} to villager type of {_villager}
villager type of {_villager} = plains
set villager type of event-entity to plains

expressions.name: Weather
expressions.description: The weather in the given or the current world.
expressions.examples:
set weather to clear
weather in "world" is rainy

expressions.name: Whether
expressions.description: A shorthand for returning the result of a condition (true or false). This is functionally identical to using `true if <condition> else false`.
expressions.examples:
set {fly} to whether player can fly
broadcast "Flying: %whether player is flying%"

expressions.name: Whitelist
expressions.description:
An expression for obtaining and modifying the server's whitelist.
Players may be added and removed from the whitelist.
The whitelist can be enabled or disabled by setting the whitelist to true or false respectively.
expressions.examples:
set the whitelist to false
add all players to whitelist
reset the whitelist

expressions.name: With Fire Resistance
expressions.description: Creates a copy of an item with (or without) fire resistance.
expressions.examples:
set {_x} to diamond sword with fire resistance
equip player with netherite helmet without fire resistance
drop fire resistant stone at player

expressions.name: World
expressions.description: The world the event occurred in.
expressions.examples:
world is "world_nether"
teleport the player to the world's spawn
set the weather in the player's world to rain
set {_world} to world of event-chunk

expressions.name: World Environment
expressions.description: The environment of a world
expressions.examples:
if environment of player's world is nether:
apply fire resistance to player for 10 minutes

expressions.name: World Seed
expressions.description: The seed of given world. Note that it will be returned as Minecraft internally treats seeds, not as you specified it in world configuration.
expressions.examples: broadcast "Seed: %seed of player's world%"

expressions.name: World from Name
expressions.description: Returns the world from a string.
expressions.examples:
world named {game::world-name}
the world "world"

expressions.name: Worlds
expressions.description: All worlds of the server, useful for looping.
expressions.examples:
loop all worlds:
broadcast "You're in %loop-world%" to loop-world

expressions.name: X Times
expressions.description: Integers between 1 and X, used in loops to loop X times.
expressions.examples:
loop 20 times:
broadcast "%21 - loop-number% seconds left.."
wait 1 second

expressions.name: X of Item
patterns: %number% of %item stacks/item types/entity type%
expressions.description: An expression to be able to use a certain amount of items where the amount can be any expression. Please note that this expression is not stable and might be replaced in the future.
expressions.examples: give level of player of pickaxes to the player

expressions.name: Yaw / Pitch
expressions.description:
The yaw or pitch of a location or vector.
A yaw of 0 or 360 represents the positive z direction. Adding a positive number to the yaw of a player will rotate it clockwise.
A pitch of 90 represents the negative y direction, or downward facing. A pitch of -90 represents upward facing. Adding a positive number to the pitch will rotate the direction downwards.
Only Paper 1.19+ users may directly change the yaw/pitch of players.
expressions.examples:
log "%player%: %location of player%, %player's yaw%, %player's pitch%" to "playerlocs.log"
set {_yaw} to yaw of player
set {_p} to pitch of target entity
set pitch of player to -90 # Makes the player look upwards, Paper 1.19+ only
add 180 to yaw of target of player # Makes the target look behind themselves

functions.name: abs
functions.description: Returns the absolute value of the argument, i.e. makes the argument positive.

functions.name: acos
functions.description: The inverse of the cosine, also called arccos. Returns result in degrees, not radians. Only returns values from 0 to 180.

functions.name: asin
functions.description: The inverse of the sine, also called arcsin. Returns result in degrees, not radians. Only returns values from -90 to 90.

functions.name: atan
functions.description: The inverse of the tangent, also called arctan. Returns result in degrees, not radians. Only returns values from -90 to 90.

functions.name: atan2
functions.description:
Similar to atan, but requires two coordinates and returns values from -180 to 180.
The returned angle is measured counterclockwise in a standard mathematical coordinate system (x to the right, y to the top).

functions.name: axisAngle
functions.description: Returns a quaternion from the given angle (in degrees) and axis (as a vector). This represents a rotation around the given axis by the given angle.

functions.name: calcExperience
functions.description: Calculates the total amount of experience needed to achieve given level from scratch in Minecraft.

functions.name: ceil
functions.description: Rounds a number up, i.e. returns the closest integer larger than or equal to the argument.

functions.name: ceiling
functions.description: Alias of ceil.

functions.name: clamp
patterns: clamp(values: numbers, min: number, max: number)
functions.description: Clamps one or more values between two numbers.

functions.name: concat
functions.description: Joins the provided texts (and other things) into a single text.
functions.examples:
concat("hello ", "there") # hello there
concat("foo ", 100, " bar") # foo 100 bar

functions.name: cos
functions.description: The cosine function. This is basically the sine shifted by 90°, i.e. cos(a) = sin(a + 90°), for any number a. Uses degrees, not radians.

functions.name: date
patterns: date(year: number, month: number, day: number, hour: number = 0, minute: number = 0, second: number = 0, millisecond: number = 0, zone_offset: number = NaN, dst_offset: number = NaN)
functions.description:
Creates a date from a year, month, and day, and optionally also from hour, minute, second and millisecond.
A time zone and DST offset can be specified as well (in minutes), if they are left out the server's time zone and DST offset are used (the created date will not retain this information).
functions.examples:
date(2014, 10, 1) # 0:00, 1st October 2014
date(1990, 3, 5, 14, 30) # 14:30, 5th May 1990
date(1999, 12, 31, 23, 59, 59, 999, -3*60, 0) # almost year 2000 in parts of Brazil (-3 hours offset, no DST)

functions.name: exp
functions.description: The exponential function. You probably don't need this if you don't know what this is.

functions.name: floor
functions.description: Rounds a number down, i.e. returns the closest integer smaller than or equal to the argument.

functions.name: formatNumber
functions.description:
Converts numbers to human-readable format. By default, '###,###' (e.g. '123,456,789') will be used for whole numbers and '###,###.##' (e.g. '123,456,789.00) will be used for decimal numbers. A hashtag '#' represents a digit, a comma ',' is used to separate numbers, and a period '.' is used for decimals.
Will return none if the format is invalid.
For further reference, see this article.
functions.examples:
command /balance:
aliases: bal
executable by: players
trigger:
set {_money} to formatNumber({money::%sender's uuid%})
send "Your balance: %{_money}%" to sender

functions.name: isNaN
functions.description: Returns true if the input is NaN (not a number).

functions.name: ln
functions.description:
The natural logarithm. You probably don't need this if you don't know what this is.
Returns NaN (not a number) if the argument is negative.

functions.name: location
patterns: location(x: number, y: number, z: number, world: world = event-world, yaw: number = 0, pitch: number = 0)
functions.description:
Creates a location from a world and 3 coordinates, with an optional yaw and pitch.
If for whatever reason the world is not found, it will fallback to the server's main world.
functions.examples:
# TELEPORTING
teleport player to location(1,1,1, world "world")
teleport player to location(1,1,1, world "world", 100, 0)
teleport player to location(1,1,1, world "world", yaw of player, pitch of player)
teleport player to location(1,1,1, world of player)
teleport player to location(1,1,1, world("world"))
teleport player to location({_x}, {_y}, {_z}, {_w}, {_yaw}, {_pitch})
# SETTING BLOCKS
set block at location(1,1,1, world "world") to stone
set block at location(1,1,1, world "world", 100, 0) to stone
set block at location(1,1,1, world of player) to stone
set block at location(1,1,1, world("world")) to stone
set block at location({_x}, {_y}, {_z}, {_w}) to stone
# USING VARIABLES
set {_l1} to location(1,1,1)
set {_l2} to location(10,10,10)
set blocks within {_l1} and {_l2} to stone
if player is within {_l1} and {_l2}:
# OTHER
kill all entities in radius 50 around location(1,65,1, world "world")
delete all entities in radius 25 around location(50,50,50, world "world_nether")
ignite all entities in radius 25 around location(1,1,1, world of player)

functions.name: log
functions.description:
A logarithm, with base 10 if none is specified. This is the inverse operation to exponentiation (for positive bases only), i.e. log(base ^ exponent, base) = exponent for any positive number 'base' and any number 'exponent'.
Another useful equation is base ^ log(a, base) = a for any numbers 'base' and 'a'.
Please note that due to how numbers are represented in computers, these equations do not hold for all numbers, as the computed values may slightly differ from the correct value.
Returns NaN (not a number) if any of the arguments are negative.

functions.name: max
functions.description: Returns the maximum number from a list of numbers.

functions.name: min
functions.description: Returns the minimum number from a list of numbers.

functions.name: mod
functions.description:
Returns the modulo of the given arguments, i.e. the remainder of the division d/m, where d and m are the arguments of this function.
The returned value is always positive. Returns NaN (not a number) if the second argument is zero.

functions.name: offlineplayer
functions.description: Returns a offline player from their name or UUID. This function will still return the player if they're online. If Paper 1.16.5+ is used, the 'allowLookup' parameter can be set to false to prevent this function from doing a web lookup for players who have not joined before. Lookups can cause lag spikes of up to multiple seconds, so use offline players with caution.
functions.examples:
set {_p} to offlineplayer("Notch")
set {_p} to offlineplayer("069a79f4-44e9-4726-a5be-fca90e38aaf5")
set {_p} to offlineplayer("Notch", false)

functions.name: player
functions.description:
Returns an online player from their name or UUID, if player is offline function will return nothing.
Setting 'getExactPlayer' parameter to true will return the player whose name is exactly equal to the provided name instead of returning a player that their name starts with the provided name.
functions.examples:
set {_p} to player("Notch") # will return an online player whose name is or starts with 'Notch'
set {_p} to player("Notch", true) # will return the only online player whose name is 'Notch'
set {_p} to player("069a79f4-44e9-4726-a5be-fca90e38aaf5") # &amp;amp;lt;none&amp;amp;gt; if player is offline

functions.name: product
functions.description: Calculates the product of a list of numbers.
functions.examples:
product(1) = 1
product(2, 3, 4) = 24
product({some list variable::*})
product(2, {_v::*}, and the player's y-coordinate)

functions.name: quaternion
patterns: quaternion(w: number, x: number, y: number, z: number)
functions.description: Returns a quaternion from the given W, X, Y and Z parameters.

functions.name: rgb
patterns: rgb(red: long, green: long, blue: long, alpha: long = 255)
functions.description: Returns a RGB color from the given red, green and blue parameters. Alpha values can be added optionally, but these only take affect in certain situations, like text display backgrounds.
functions.examples:
dye player's leggings rgb(120, 30, 45)
set the colour of a text display to rgb(10, 50, 100, 50)

functions.name: round
functions.description: Rounds a number, i.e. returns the closest integer to the argument. Place a second argument to define the decimal placement.

functions.name: sin
functions.description: The sine function. It starts at 0° with a value of 0, goes to 1 at 90°, back to 0 at 180°, to -1 at 270° and then repeats every 360°. Uses degrees, not radians.

functions.name: sqrt
functions.description:
The square root, which is the inverse operation to squaring a number (for positive numbers only). This is the same as (argument) ^ (1/2) – other roots can be calculated via number ^ (1/root), e.g. set {_l} to {_volume}^(1/3).
Returns NaN (not a number) if the argument is negative.

functions.name: sum
functions.description: Sums a list of numbers.
functions.examples:
sum(1) = 1
sum(2, 3, 4) = 9
sum({some list variable::*})
sum(2, {_v::*}, and the player's y-coordinate)

functions.name: tan
functions.description: The tangent function. This is basically sin(arg)/cos(arg). Uses degrees, not radians.

functions.name: uuid
functions.description: Returns a UUID from the given string. The string must be in the format of a UUID.

functions.name: vector
patterns: vector(x: number, y: number, z: number)
functions.description: Creates a new vector, which can be used with various expressions, effects and functions.

functions.name: world
functions.description: Gets a world from its name.
